Sheâ€™s putting Nigerian cuisine on the map!  Hilda Effiong Bassey is a popular Nigerian chef known on social media as Hilda Baci, CNN reports. Motivated by her Naija roots, Bassey set out to set a new world record for her home country, hosting a marathon to cook the most consecutive nonstop hours by an individual. Hosted in Lagos, Bassey worked to beat the previous record of 87 hours and 45 minutes set in 2019 by Indian chef Lata Tondon. Tondon sent in her well wishes via social media as Bassey began cooking on Thursday, finishing up on Monday and setting a new world record with a whopping 100 hours of nonstop cooking.  Bassey said her motivation for the challenge was putting Nigerian food on the global radar, creating over 55 recipes and more than 100 recipes throughout the cookathon.  â€œNigerian cuisine is the best out there. The more recipes are propagated, the more people will be willing to try it. Nigerian food is such comfort food,â€ Bassey told reporters.  Many showed up in droves to support the chef as she danced and waved at fans from her kitchen. Popular Nigerian artist Tiwa Savage visited Bassey to encourage her along with politicians, the Governor of Lagos state, reporters and locals, including Udak Obong who traveled through the night to come out.  â€œI drove 12 hours to be right here to support my sister, my friend. Sheâ€™s just amazing,â€ said Obong.    Enioluwa Adeoluwa, an influencer who served as MC for the cooking marathon said this type of community is common in Nigeria and they were all supportive of Basseyâ€™s efforts.  â€œWhen a Nigerian is doing something we all come out to show supportâ€¦We are super excited. Sheâ€™s doing such an amazing job.  Bassey admitted that the journey was laborious, saying she even thought about quitting, but with the massive amounts of support shown, she pushed through and was happy to accomplish such a major feat.  â€œThe first day was the most difficult. I was ready to give up 6 hours in. I feel like a miracle happened and somehow I got to this. The support has been incredible,â€ said Bassey.  She is still waiting for the Guinness world record committee to confirm that all criteria has been met before officially naming Bassey as the new record holder. But all of Nigeria and the diaspora agrees that after cooking for 100 hours straight, Bassey has just blazed a trail that will open doors for generations of chefs to come.  â€œSheâ€™s opening the door to the African food market and showing all the youth out here that if you can dream it, you can achieve it,â€ said actor Damilola Ogunsi.  Congratulations Chef Bassey!  Chef Hilda Bassey breaks world record after cooking for 100 hours/Photo Courtesy of Tobi Loke/@HildaBaci/Instagram

It was a family affair at the Westville Music Bowl in New Haven, CT for Joe Russo's Almost Dead on May 13, 2023, as the daughters of both Joe Russo and Marco Benevento joined the band on stage during this late spring, pre-Mother's Day event. This show marked the first show on the Westville's calendar for 2023, and had over 4600 fans in attendance for this most righteous Dead cover band.  The evening's festivities began on a lovely New England afternoon. The band took the stage around 6:15pm, and wasted no time by diving into an exploratory build up prior to "Eyes of the World." Drummer Joe Russo dug into deep percussion early, and keyboardist Marco Benevento unfurled a beautiful sequence on the piano. A bluesy jam ensued, followed by a funky transition into "The Music Never Stopped." The vibe became mellow as the music flowed into a "Black Peter" tease, but quickly picked up, with a raging guitar jam via guitarists Tom Hamilton and Scott Metzger back into "The Music Never Stopped."  Joe Russo welcomed his two young daughters with pint-sized guitars on stage before the band performed "Here Comes The Sun" for the first time. Both Russo and Hamilton contributed vocals to this classic Beatles' tune. The girls remained for the rest of the set, and unleashed a few rock star moves of their own.  A very spacey jam lead into "Estimated Prophet," proceeded by a layered jam, with notable contributions by Metzger. A slower, more melodic improvisational section gave way for an edgy jam into "The Wheel," with an emphasis by bassist Dave Dreiwitz. Both Dreiwitz and Hamilton raced through an incredible build up that transformed into a perfectly placed "Real Morning Party" tease, which is a song by Benevento. The music rolled into a deliciously psychedelic "Uncle John's Band," before these fine musicians stopped for a breath of air. With Russo like a freight train on the drums, "Bertha," was up next, and concluded this stellar set.  The band returned for round two, and picked up where they left off with "St. Stephen." This raging opener lead into more improvisational pleasantries on the piano by Benevento. The guitars elevated this jam, ushering the music back into "St. Stephen," before a face melting segue into "I Need a Miracle." I need a miracle everyday, indeed. The crowd assisted Metzger with these famous lyrics, followed by a boot scooting, bluesy breakdown. The music rolled into a euphonious "Ramble On Rose," with a breezy jam by Hamilton.  More psychedelic goodness emerged with "Scarlet Begonias," which flowed into a reggae inspired improvisation that was almost spooky at times. Benevento's daughters Illa and Ruby joined their father on the keys as the band moved into a heated "Fire on the Mountain." The layers of piano brought a huge smile to proud papa Benevento. This tune was all Hamilton, from the soulful vocals to the galvanized jam. After returning to "Scarlet Begonias," Russo announced, "It's daughter night here at JRAD. Big hand for Illa and Ruby Benevento. It's feeling like Father's Day on Mother's Day. We're just lucky to be here. Happy Mother's Day."  The music was not over quite yet, as this talented bunch served up a monster, sixteen minute "Throwing Stones" that went into type two territory. A melodious jam skillfully jettisoned back into "Throwing Stones." The set ended on the heart felt "So Many Roads." The band returned to play a high energy "Good Lovin," which returned to "The Wheel," before ending the show with an affirmative bang.  Joe Russo's Almost Dead always brings fresh jams and vibrant tunes. We as fans are extremely lucky to experience music from them with their children, on top of that. They are back in action on June 3 - 4 at Red Rocks Amphitheater in Morrison, Co. Head on over to their tour page for more details on their summer tour.  Check out more photos from the show!  Set One: Eyes of the World -> The Music Never Stopped1, Here Comes the Sun23, Estimated Prophet -> The Wheel45 > Uncle John's Band, Bertha  Set Two: St. Stephen > I Need A Miracle > Ramble On Rose, Scarlet Begonias -> Fire on the Mountain6, Throwing Stones > So Many Roads  Encore: Good Lovin7  Notes:  1. Black Peter tease  2. First time played  3. With Joe Russo's daughters  4. The Real Morning Party tease  5. Here Comes the Sun tease  6. With Illa and Ruby Benevento  7. The Wheel tease

(Bloomberg) -- Markets are betting on a rocky end to the debt-ceiling debate roiling Washington, but if they are wrong, investors may miss out on the gains.  Most Read from Bloomberg  Thatâ€™s the thinking of Amy Wu Silverman, head of derivatives strategy at RBC Capital Markets.  â€œThe tale of optimism does not exist,â€ she told Bloomberg Television. â€œIs there a possibility of a congressional miracle? Who knows â€” but right now folks are pricing that this is going to be a very tumultuous debt ceiling. If it at all comes in a little bit easier than we expect, that right tail is very cheap.â€  The volatility market is looking for action in stocks, and equities need to drawdown before Congress takes action, she said, adding that she expects an â€œeleventh hour, 2011-typeâ€ situation. Wall Streetâ€™s â€œfear gauge,â€ the Cboe Volatility Index or VIX, has been trading below 30 â€” a level considered a sign of heightened volatility â€” for most of 2023. The VIX was also tamped down in 2011 amid a similar standoff around the debt ceiling before it peaked near 50 in August and remained above 30.  â€œThatâ€™s what these bets in the market are saying right now,â€ she said. â€œThey think weâ€™re going to get back there.â€  Lawmakers took a cautiously optimistic tone after a Tuesday meeting between President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, saying that while they remained far apart, parties were hopeful they could find some middle ground. Contracts on the S&P 500 rose in premarket trading on Wednesday morning.  Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has warned that her department could run out of cash as soon as June 1. Rates on short-dated Treasuries expiring around that so-called X-date have soared, but analysts have pointed to a lack of reaction from equity markets, with the benchmark gauge stuck in a narrow range.  Story continues  Silverman explained that the VIX is low because bullish S&P calls are cheap, and she pointed to â€œbearishness across the board.â€  â€œThe most underpriced reality right now is the idea that this debt ceiling situation actually gets resolved quicker and easier than we think,â€ she said. â€œFolks are very, very well prepared for a debacle. And so if we donâ€™t get it, it would be very interesting to see all these hedges roll off.â€  --With assistance from Jonathan Ferro and Tom Keene. Three of his earliest works, bundled together as the â€œOTTO Trilogy,â€ trace what the Gladstone Gallery called â€œthe training, discipline, and physical limits of the body alongside questions of sexual difference and desire.â€ Centered around former football player Jim Otto, not only is his name a palindrome, but his uniform number â€œ00â€ suggests the infinity symbol and the concept of doubling while also working as a visual depiction of cellular meiosisâ€”that is, the cell division of gametes, sex cells, in sexually-reproducing organisms. It seems like heady stuff, and itâ€™s true that avant-garde cinema is not for every taste, but thereâ€™s an intoxicating compulsion and approachability to Barneyâ€™s work. His is the stuff of violent mass spectacle, human achievements on grand architectural and operatic scales, secret societies, and arcane rituals, and how the miracle of it all that creation is just an imperfect, Frankensteinian mirror to the mysterious and overlooked functions of biology.  Barneyâ€™s work emerges from tension, the titles of his pieces providing the ends of threads that, once pulled, open him up for contemplation, contextualization, and sometimes dissection. He is known for an ongoing video and photography series called Drawing Restraint, which describes a line between muscle growth and artistic production; River of Fundament is a three-act opera based on Norman Mailerâ€™s Ancient Evenings; â€œRedoubtâ€ employs the voyeurism and punishment myth of Diana and Actaeon in the exploration of what he called â€œhumanityâ€™s place in the natural worldâ€; and now â€œSecondary,â€ which dramatizes a fateful American football game in which Patriots wide receiver Darryl Stingley is paralyzed in 1978 by a violent hit from Oakland Raiders defensive back Jack Tatum. Moving between the worlds of fine art and provocation, Barney is probably best known for his epic, eight-year, and five-film project â€œThe Cremaster Cycleâ€ (398 min), undertaken between 1994 and 2002.  Metrograph is hosting a rare screening of all five parts in the order in which they were created, which is not the order in which they are numbered, culminating with an in-person conversation with Barney and frequent collaborator Maggie Nelson. It is the first New York screening of this work since 2015. Barney has vowed there never be a broad home video incarnation.  â€œThe Cremaster Cycleâ€ is named for the muscle in male anatomy primarily responsible for raising and lowering testes in response to temperature. Its most disturbing, and arguably most sophisticated sequence is in the middle of its final and longest installment, â€œCremaster 3,â€ in which its wordless hero, The Entered Apprentice (played by Barney himself), is strapped into a dentistâ€™s chair at the center of the Chrysler Building, partially stripped and forced to ingest the crushed metal sepulcher, a violently-compressed 1938 Chevrolet Imperial, of serial murderer Gary Gilmore. Gilmore is played by Barney in â€œCremaster 2â€ as a being born from a seance, gestated in a fleshy umbilicus stretched between two cars parked at a remote gas station, where the killer murdered attendant Max Jensen (Michael Thompson).

DIGNAN  Arthur Grant Dignan, 83, of Jefferson City, Missouri, passed away peacefully Friday, May 12, 2023, at SSM Heath St. Maryâ€™s Hospital.  He was born in Jacksonville, Florida on November 14, 1939, a son to the late Peter Arthur and Jewel Edith (Miracle) Dignan.  On June 17, 1972, he was united in marriage to Joyce Ann Bradley in Akron, Ohio.  Arthur was a 1958 graduate of Florida School for the Deaf and Blind. For seven years after graduating, he worked as a typesetter for a newspaper where he was self-taught. He then attended Gallaudet University in Washington D.C. where he studied and graduated with his degree in Sociology in 1971. Arthur began working as a teacher at Montana School for the Deaf for two years. Before going on to further his education, he would marry the love of his life in 1972. He then attended California State Northridge where he gained his Masterâ€™s in Education.  After achieving his first Masterâ€™s degree, he and Joyce moved back to Florida where they welcomed their first son, and he started teaching at his high school alma mater. His family then moved to Utah and he taught at Utah School for the Deaf. It was in Utah that his brother-in-law, Raymond Bradley, would lead Arthur and Joyce to Christ in 1977, and they would welcome their second son. This year was a life-changing year for him and his young family.  Arthur went on to teach at various other institutions for the deaf including California School for the Deaf, Southwest Collegiate Institute of the Deaf, and Oklahoma School for the Deaf. While teaching in Big Spring, Texas, he would welcome his third child and only daughter. He decided to continue his education and received his second Masterâ€™s degree, which was in Counseling. After this achievement, he would continue to teach at schools in Florida, California, Kentucky, and Pennsylvania, before making a final move to Missouri where he taught at William Woods University from 1996 until his retirement.  He was incredibly dedicated to the deaf community. Arthur was a true pioneer for the deaf culture and for sign language. Nationally known for his influence in the deaf community, he made a way for individuals to know that they can succeed and have the best things in life. He truly made a long-lasting, positive impact on the world that will continue to bless people for generations to come.  Arthur was a very brilliant, dedicated, and driven man. Along with his many accomplishments in education and career, he was also successful in creative ventures. For many years he had a one-man comedy show, authored a book, and acted in a movie about the Book of Job. He was actively engaged in his church life where he was a deaf leader, Sunday school teacher, and held various leadership positions. His love for God and people shone through everything that he did.  It is important to note that Arthur was a huge football fan. He was successful in the sport, earning the title of All-American in high school. His passion for the game would be passed down to his sons who also earned the All-American title, and eventually would trickle down to his grandchildren. Their common love of the game created an extremely special bond.  After his retirement from teaching, Arthurâ€™s main goal and priority was spending time with his family and grandchildren. He loved attending his grandkidsâ€™ sporting events and rarely missed a ball game. He never missed church, always showed up with a smile, and loved being involved. Even when his health began to decline, Arthur never complained. His family was his greatest pride and he loved them deeply. He will be missed immensely by those who know and love him.  He is survived by the love of his life and wife of nearly 51 years, Joyce; children, Randy (Janelle) Dignan of Jefferson City, Nick (Ashley) Dignan of Groves, Texas, and Jennifer (Jorge) Morales of New Bloomfield; grandchildren, Briella, Rayana, Grant, and Clara Dignan, Cade Madelyn, Colt Arthur, and McKinley Ann Dignan, and Amelia, Benton, Conan, Darrion, and Emalie Morales; nephew, Philip Van Dignan; niece, Nelda Knapik; and numerous additional nieces and nephews.  He was preceded in death by his parents, Peter and Edith; and brother, Philip Dignan.  Friends will be received on Thursday, May 18, 2023, from 2:15 p.m. â€“ 3:45 p.m. at Bible Baptist Church in Jefferson City. A funeral service will begin at 4:00 p.m. with his sons, Randy and Nick Dignan, officiating.  Expressions of sympathy may be made to the Deaf Fund of Bible Baptist Church in memory of Arthur.  Arrangements are under the direction of HOUSER-MILLARD Funeral Directors, 2613 West Main Street; Jefferson City, MO 65109. (573) 636-3838.  Condolences may be left for the family online at www.millardfamilychapels.com

At the press conference for the film at Cannes, Depp talked about â€œabstract whispersâ€ and said that â€œthe majority of what you have been reading the last four or five yearsâ€¦with regard to me and my life what youâ€™ve read is fantastically, horrifically written fiction.â€

Tobias Frank Welby was travelling with his aunt, Frankie Jules-Hough, and two cousins, Rocky, two, and Tommy, nine, when the family were involved in a horrific car crash on the M66 near Bury on Saturday (May 13).  The family were airlifted to hospital from the scene, between junction 3 for the Pilsworth Interchange and junction 4 for Simister Island.  Tragically, 38-year-old Frankie, who was 18 weeks pregnant, died from her injuries on Monday (May 15).  A 22-year-old man, Adil Iqbal, of Hope Street in Accrington, has been charged with causing Frankie's death by dangerous driving as well as two other charges of causing serious injury by dangerous driving, relating to the two boys.  Tributes have since been pouring in for the Chadderton mum-of-two and a fundraiser for the family has amassed more than Â£40,000.  Meanwhile, two of the boys, Tobias and his cousin, Tommy, have been in critical care at Manchester Royal Hospital.  In an update, Tobias' parents, Becci and Arron Welby, said their "hearts ache inside" as their son has been placed in an induced coma with a brain injury and fractured skull.  Calling him their "brave boy" and "our warrior", the pair said Tobias faces a long road to recovery, "but our precious boy is fighting".  "The medical specialists are doing their best around the clock while our family tries to make sense of what has happened.  "We ride this emotional rollercoaster day by day, minute by minute", they added.  A photograph of the boy in his hospital bed has also been posted on social media.  The family said they "battled with the decision" to post the heartbreaking image.  The Welbys added: "My son is strong, a fighter and we have faith.  "We have had some positive news today from his most recent brain scan but we are not out of the woods, the doctors tell us to take it slow day by day.  "Every day we hope for continued miracles.  "He and his cousin both are proving how strong they can be and are currently stable.  "Our hearts ache inside."  They said they are currently finding comfort in prayer and each other, and believe "in our core" that the amazing team at the hospital, as well as the fast action of first responders on the scene of the crash, "that our boys will keep improving day by day".  "Tobias, mummy and daddy are waiting for you. You are our whole world", they added.  Iqbal appeared in the dock at Manchester Magistratesâ€™ Court on Monday afternoon. No pleas were entered. The case was adjourned for a preliminary hearing at Minshull Street Crown Court on June 19. He was remanded into custody until the next hearing.

Guest Viewpoints  Easter is the Christian celebration of Jesus Christâ€™s miraculous triumph over death. After His death by crucifixion, He rose from the dead three days later. The Christian belief is that Jesus sacrificed Himself on the cross and bore the sins of all the people. His Resurrection grants eternal life for all those who believe in Him, and the celebration of Easter stands as one of the most important and holy days on the Christian calendar.  Orthodox Easter, or Pascha and Catholic Easter, have the same roots and both celebrate the miracle of resurrection. The main difference is they are celebrated on different days. The Catholics follow a different calendar than the Orthodox; Orthodox Easter usually falls after Catholic Easter.  Greek Orthodox Easter holds unique traditions different from the Catholic traditions. Worshippers work together to bring the miracle of resurrection to life.  Preparations for Pascha begin 40 days prior to Easter; Greeks would commence in fasting, prayer, and the attendance of liturgy services during this time. Great Lent prepares believers to reach for, accept, and attain the calling of their Savior. Observance of Great Lent calls for the abstinence of many foods including all meat and dairy, repentance, and restitution for all sins committed in the past year. The duration of this period is finalized on the Sunday of the sixth week, Palm Sunday, which celebrates the beginning of Holy Week. Jesusâ€™ arrival in Jerusalem, where He was greeted by people waving palm branches. Worshippers welcome Jesus into their hearts and show their willingness to follow Him by this greeting. The Palm Sunday tradition is that all gather in the church prior to the Divine Liturgy and fold the palm leaves into cross shapes. The church is then decorated with the palm leaves. Concluding the Palm Sunday mass, the priest distributes the blessed palm crosses to all as a symbol of victory and peace.  The church services during Holy Week run for hours, and there is a different service every day to follow the Passion of Christ, the days that led Him to the cross, and to Resurrection, according to the Greek Reporter website.  On Holy Wednesday, the Liturgy of the Presanctified Gifts is held. This evening is devoted to repentance, confession, and the remission of sins by the Lord. Those who attend are given the opportunity to repent their sins in Confession in preparation for communion. The service closes with the priest blessing each person with anointing oil, which many people believe has healing powers.  Holy Thursday follows with a depressing liturgy as Jesusâ€™ betrayal is recalled and He is eventually led to His death. Four events are celebrated on this day and the â€˜Twelve Gospelsâ€™ are read during service to prepare for Good Friday.  On Good Friday, the people are in mourning and the church bells ring throughout Greece to commemorate the death of Jesus Christ. People will gather at the church Friday night to participate in a funeral procession for Jesus. They follow the priest and the â€˜Epitafiosâ€™, a wooden construction carrying the precious cloth depicting the body of Christ and adorned with flowers. Mourners are given candles with red cups, and all share the holy light as they walk outside to mourn their savior. The processions are accompanied by a police escort, and the roads are closed for them to walk. People must be extra careful while holding the candles as there have been many instances where coats and even hair have accidentally caught fire. The Good Friday Procession is arguably the most renowned event of Holy Week, as it thoroughly recreates the biblical scenes and brings the story of Easter to life.  On Holy Saturday, or the service of the â€˜Anastasiâ€™, Greeks gather at the church at midnight for the Resurrection ceremony. Greeks ditch the dark-colored Good Friday Candles for white candles, or â€˜lampathesâ€™. Lampathes are gifted to children by their godfather or godmother and are often decorated. Children keep their lampathes for the year as they have been blessed by being lit from the Holy Flame that comes from Jerusalem. At midnight, the priests join the Greeks outside the church and chant â€œChristos Anesti!â€ and the people respond â€œAlithos Anesti!â€ This can be translated to, â€œChrist is risen,â€ â€œTruly, He is risen,â€ respectively. Greeks celebrate Christâ€™s Resurrection and pass around the Holy Light to bring home and bless their houses.  Returning home from Midnight vigil, it is customary to make a cross out of candle smoke above the front door to symbolize the Resurrection. Then, it is time to celebrate.  The family sits around the table to crack red eggs, symbolic of the blood and tomb of Christ. Everyone gets an egg, and it becomes a competition to see whose egg is the strongest. Families will go around the table saying the phrase â€œChristos Anesti,â€ â€œAlithos Anesti,â€ as they smash their eggs against each other. The person with the strongest egg is said to have good luck for the next year.  After eating the eggs, the traditional midnight meal is served. â€˜Magiritsaâ€™ is a special Greek soup made with lamb intestines, kidneys, and other innards. It has a distinct taste and most definitely does not appeal to everyone, but it serves as a festive way to signify the end of the 40-day fasting period.  The Easter celebrations continue throughout the day, where Greeks prepare to break their fast and enjoy lamb. The lamb is traditionally cooked for hours, rotating on a spit, which can serve as a frightful sight for a young child, or non-Greeks. â€˜Tsourekiâ€™, a sweet bread, is also prepared and served at the Easter table. Food is an integral part of Greek Easter, and most anticipate this feast all year.  Greek Easter is a day full of family, dancing, food, and celebrating. It is a day meant to be spent with loved ones. People are given a chance of rebirth as they repent their sins as they honor Jesusâ€™ death. The belief is that Jesus died for the sins of the people, and with the miracle of His Resurrection, people are given a second chance. The traditions of Greek Easter help to preserve this miracle and allow people to experience the true story. It enhances the authenticity of the celebration, and stands as a resurrection for all.  Alexis Raynor, is a junior at Lynbrook High School in Lynbrook, NY. She is a managing editor for Horizon, her high schoolâ€™s newspaper, which originally published the above article â€“ which has been lightly edited here by The National Herald â€“ online on April 2 and in its print edition on May 5.

click to enlarge  Wow! What a winter!  Breaking all records, the long drought has ended and, at least temporarily, plentiful precipitation has saved the day.  Itâ€™s given new meaning to the moniker, â€œGreatest Snow on Earth,â€ which fell â€œgreatlyâ€ in all-time record amounts across the stateâ€”over 900 inches at Altaâ€”and clobbered the mountains across both central and southern Utah. Not everyone is happy; the ear-nose-and-throat specialists will have a â€œdry seasonâ€ and the gastroenterologists will be scraping for business.  Confused? To the dismay of those particular medical specialties, Utahns will be cured of their dry coughs and will no longer be hopelessly resigned to â€œfarting dust.â€ Drink up, folks!  Itâ€™s just one more disastrous crisis averted in Utahâ€™s roller-coaster history that will likely be attributed to a miracle. Surely, Gov. Spencer Cox and most of the residents were praying that the drought would end, saving our much-treasured, amply-sized lawns and the trees that were never meant to grow here, and ensuring that Utahâ€™s biggest industryâ€”ski tourismâ€”would continue its healthy growth.  The renewed water supply will also mean that pink flamingos will, once again, choose to vacation on the shores of the Great Salt Lake, and that the wandering naturists will be able to see water during their Sunday walks on the GSL shore.  Utahâ€™s invariably-temporary end of the drought is likely to become another folk legend. Itâ€™ll go something like this in the history books: â€œLuckily, the seagulls had been poised and ready for takeoff. Flying from California, with their buckets of snow, they managed to make the 2022-2023 ski seasons one of the most profitable ever, dumping more than 30 inches of water and delighting everyone with endless schussing.â€ Then again, maybe that white stuffâ€”all 75 feet of itâ€”wasnâ€™t snow at all! Ha-ha.  What, but a miracle, could explain the bonanza of welcome water? Sure, the relentless â€œatmospheric riversâ€ of moisture were an essential element, but we need to remember that itâ€™s the â€œlake effectâ€ that plays such a big part in the Wasatch Mountains' annual snowfall. Without those unique evaporative lake-effect contributions to the Wasatch snow depths, Utahâ€™s northern ski resorts would have far less snow. Itâ€™s frankly amazing that so much snow could have fallen during a season when the GSL had retained only about 75% of its total surface areaâ€”shorted of almost 800 square miles of evaporative capability. Thatâ€™s a miracle!  Sadly, thereâ€™s truth in the adage, â€œBe careful what you pray for.â€ Record precipitation is presenting the possibility of a replay of SLCâ€™s 1983 snowmelt, when rivers flowed on the cityâ€™s primary thoroughfares after record temperatures changed the snow to wild torrents. Should that happen, we should try to have the seagulls ready and waiting, using their buckets, once again, to save the day.  Despite the ailing Brigham Youngâ€™s hearty verbal embrace of the vision before him when he arrived at the Salt Lake Valleyâ€” â€œThis is the right placeâ€â€”Utah has not exactly been the perfect spot to settle and thrive. Fraught with problems from the very beginning, itâ€™s been a challenging location for living. Its high-altitude aridity is an unavoidable fact. Nevertheless, Youngâ€™s dreamy prediction of making the â€œdesert blossom as a roseâ€ has been mostly spot-on. Chalk it up to ingenuity, some fortuitous luck, and lots of hard work, Utah and the Valley of the Great Salt Lake have become a remarkably successful venture, one that would have surely baffled its early detractors.  Arriving late in the year 1847, the Mormon pioneers lost no time in planting the crops theyâ€™d need to sustain them through the next year, but autumn conditions didnâ€™t favor a bounteous harvest, and they barely survived. The spring of 1848 brought a second planting of crops, and those did pretty well until a hoard of â€œMormon" crickets (not sure they had actually been baptized) descended from the skies. The pioneers exclaimed, â€œOh, sh-t!â€ and things looked pretty grim.  We all know the story: The people prayed and then, voila! A flock of hungry seagulls, divinely conscripted for that specific campaign, descended on the crickets and ate every last one of those crunchy little critters. That event became a popular folk legend, though some historians have questioned whether the birds actually saved the day or only made a small contribution. Most important, miracle or not, the settlers enjoyed a healthy harvest and were able to make it through another winter.  But, thatâ€™s not where the legends about seagulls end. Despite the rudeness of Californiansâ€”describing the garbage-eating and disease-carrying birds as â€œflying ratsâ€â€”it is rumored that seagulls equipped with special saddles brought a plentiful array of pretty, young women to early Salt Lake City, who, at just the right moment, parachuted into the fledgling town, and helped Young to fill all vacancies in his 56-wife harem. Yes, thatâ€™s right; the seagulls, once again, provided fortuitous relief to the problems of the saints. And we all know now that those 56 wives contributed to wildly-plentiful offspring and a permanent economic and political â€œYoungâ€ dynasty.  Utah is a great state. Endowed with amazing natural wonders and geological treats, replete with intelligent and industrious people, blessed with one of the best economies and lowest jobless rates, it stands as a living monument to the American Dream.  Itâ€™s certainly worth asking: Without the seagulls, where would we be today? Audubon would be proud.  The author is a retired novelist, columnist and former Vietnam-era Army assistant public information officer. He resides in Riverton with his wife, Carol, and the beloved ashes of their mongrel dog.

The journey to motherhood is different for every woman. Sometimes traditional approaches to motherhood do not work and when they fail that is when women on the journey begin taking different paths to motherhood. Alison Murray is a woman whose motherhood journey includes becoming a blended family, pregnancy and loss, adoption and a miracle. Murrayâ€™s story is as much a story of the journey to motherhood as it is a testament to faith and seeking professional support and resources unapologetically.  EBONY spoke with Murray to discuss her unique path to motherhood and to hear the lessons she has learned from her journey to motherhood.  EBONY: What was your journey to motherhood?  Alison Murray: My journey to motherhood is not what I dreamed it would be. I had it all planned out in my mind after I got married. Dwayne [her husband] and I would wait a couple of years and then start growing our family. What I wasn't thinking or appreciating at the time was the fact that I became a mother the moment I got married, as I gained my bonus son, Deuce. So, as planned, we waited a few years and then started trying to conceive. The desert that I would find myself in over the next seven years would be so devastating, I seriously doubted whether motherhood would be a reality for me. After four second-trimester miscarriages, one infant loss, and the miracle of our two sons (one through adoption and the other live birth), I can humbly say that my journey to motherhood has been one fraught with so many trials but ultimately one of triumph.  What led to your decision to adopt?  The decision to adopt came after our second pregnancy loss. I was sitting in church while a presentation was being given about adoption and fundraising to support birthmothers associated with a local adoption agency. My stepson gave me a hard jab to my ribs and then a not-so-secretive nod to the pulpit. Dwayne was in the choir loft, so I had no idea what he was thinking. However, after church, we started to have an initial discussion about what going down the path of adoption would mean for our family. It was not a backup plan or a second option. We desperately wanted to add to our family, and we were presented with a way that we honestly hadn't considered. The adoption process is not for the faint of heart, and we learned and are still learning that the process is a challenging one.  How did you overcome miscarriages and loss during your journey?  I didn't. I'm still not over them. Even when I was finally able to give birth to my son, the scars of that time and trauma remain. After Joshua died, the doctors forced me to take a break from trying. That was a very difficult space to be in. I was 35 and thought that the door was closing. What I held onto was that Joshua was the first child to survive, albeit a short time outside my body. Joshua was God's promise that Malachi was coming. That's why I advocate so heavily for mental health for those dealing with infertility, grief, and bereavement from pregnancy loss and infant loss. Therapy saved my marriage and my life. It gave me space to work out all my thoughts and emotions. To be quite honest, I still don't attend baby showers. It's a personal preference. One of my mantras is "Protect my space and Protect my peace". Gently declining things like baby showers are how I accomplish that. But I still make sure the momma-to-be gets an awesome gift.  What words of encouragement or advice would you offer to other women on a similar journey to motherhood?  No journey is the same. In the valleys or the desert, it's okay not to be okay. Try to hold on to "your happy". Most importantly, lean on Romans 8:28. He hasn't failed me yet, and I know He won't fail you either.

Winnie-Rae Southgate was just 1lb 2 ounces she was born on October 10, 2022 - 13 weeks early.  The baby girl from Ipswich spent 171 days at Addenbrooke's Hospital and an additional 33 days at Ipswich Hospital.  There every step of the way were her parents Keâ€™Anne Holroyd and Ash Southgate.  Winnie-Rae Southgate with her parents, Keâ€™Anne Holroyd and Ash Southgate, Supplied (Image: Supplied)  The 28-year-old first-time mum said: "Winnie-Rae was delivered by an emergency C-section.  "We got admitted to Addenbrookeâ€™s two weeks before she was actually born. When she started to struggle inside me and her heart rate was dropping, the doctors decided to deliver her early.  "We knew that she was going to be a low birth weight, but we didnâ€™t expect her to be extremely low, weighing only 530 grammes.  Winnie-Rae was born 13 weeks earlier than planned, Supplied (Image: Supplied)  "When she arrived, we were told there was a low chance that she would survive, which is obviously hard to hear for parents."  Miss Holroyd said that Winnie-Rae's loud cry during the delivery gave her hope that everything was going to be well.  She added: "When I saw her for the first time, she looked like a little bird fallen out of the nest, all just skin and bone.  Winnie-Rae was born 13 weeks earlier than planned, Supplied (Image: Supplied)  "We were just told that we had to take it hour by hour."  The parents stayed at a charity-run hotel at Addenbrooke's Hospital and were supported by other family members.  Winnie-Rae is nothing but a fighter, battling chronic lung disease and metabolic bone disease, a large PDA (hole in the heart), Klebsiella sepsis, among an array of serious challenges.  Her mum added that Winnie-Rae made a huge improvement under the care of Ipswich Hospital staff.  Then the big day came, Wednesday, May 3, when the family was able to take Winnie-Rae home - more than 200 days after she was born.  Winnie-Rae's parents celebrated that day by getting engaged, after going through one of the toughest journeys parents can experience.  Miss Holroyd added they are very happy that their daughter is home after spending more than half a year in hospitals but are also a bit scared of not having nursesâ€™ support 24/7.  She added: "It's just that worry of her getting ill because she's so small and she's still on the oxygen support.  "Sheâ€™s got a feeding tube and stoma, which is a lot for a parent to take in.  "Sheâ€™ll need her oxygen support until her lungs grow enough.  "We've been told that she can potentially come off that when sheâ€™s two.  "Her stoma reversal should happen when she's a toddler also, so it all depends on how she grows.  Winnie-Rae is now home with her parents, Supplied (Image: Supplied)  "Itâ€™s all important, but the most important thing is just having her home."  Winnie-Rae's great aunt, Astra Sansiviero, opened an online fundraising to celebrate her 40th birthday and to say a big â€˜thank youâ€™ for the help the family received from Addenbrookeâ€™s Charitable Trust.  She said: "This remarkable little one is super fierce and has the strength from her parents, who have been by her side all the way.  "As a family, we are eternally grateful for the love, care, compassion, and kindness from all those who supported Winnie on this journey.  "Please show some support for this amazing charity and donate what you can, the target is Â£204, which represents every day Winnie-Rae spent in hospital receiving lifesaving care and treatment, every bit helps. Thank you."  Support the fundraising here.

Stefano Pioli has admitted that there is disappointment after AC Milan lost yet another derby to exit the Champions League at the semi-final stage.  There was to be no miracle comeback from AC Milan as they lost 1-0 on the night against Inter and 3-0 on aggregate, crashing out in the semi-finals but also losing a fourth derby in a row against the Nerazzurri in which they did not score.  Edin Dzeko and Henrikh Mkhitaryanâ€™s goals in the first leg meant that a minor miracle was needed to reach the final in Istanbul next month, but it never came and Lautaro Martinezâ€™s goal in the second half last night stamped Interâ€™s ticket.  Pioli spoke to Mediaset after the game to try and reflect on what was obviously a memorable run for the team deep into the competition, but another hurdle fallen at when it comes to their city rivals.  â€œItâ€™s a big disappointment, letâ€™s face it. Weâ€™ve had a great journey in the Champions League yes, also thinking about what we did last year, but we wanted to get to the final because that counts. There is disappointment,â€ he said (via MilanNews).  â€œUnfortunately we conditioned this semi-final with the first 15 minutes of the first leg, then for the rest we were up to a very strong team.  â€œWe had two chances to reopen the tie I canâ€™t reproach my players for anything. We tried with everything we had. Now we have to finish the season well, it would be a shameâ€¦  â€œThe regrets are clearly for the first few minutes of the first leg, but then Inter won both games, not really dominating. Today much more similar to the second half of the first leg. Then we didnâ€™t manage to score.  â€œWe were doing well with positions, we lacked quality and precision. I was preparing changes and we conceded, then the match was almost over there.  â€œWe werenâ€™t able to be as dangerous as we usually are, due to Interâ€™s compactness and a pace and precision that should have been better.  â€œWe tried today, but we werenâ€™t as precise and composed. Inter in these matches scored against us with their first chances, we werenâ€™t able to do the same thing.â€

(San Mateo County Sheriff's Office via AP, File)  Newly unsealed court documents show that the wife of a California radiologist accused of trying to kill his family by driving over a cliff told rescuers he was depressed and needed a psychological evaluation  REDWOOD CITY, Calif. -- The wife of a California radiologist accused of trying to kill his family when he drove his Tesla off a cliff along the Northern California coast told rescuers her husband was depressed and needed a psychological evaluation, according to a newly unsealed search warrant affidavit.  The San Francisco Chronicle reported Wednesday that Neha Patel repeatedly told rescuers that Dharmesh Patel intentionally drove off a San Mateo County cliff on Jan. 2 in a bid to kill her and their two children, ages 4 and 7. All four survived in what one official called an â€œabsolute miracle.â€  Dharmesh Patel, a Pasadena radiologist, said he pulled off the road to check on a possibly flat tire, according to the warrant. Witness testimony does not appear to back up his account.  â€œHe drove off. Heâ€™s depressed," Neha Patel told a California Highway Patrol officer as she was flown away from the crash site, according to the Chronicle. â€œHe said he was going to drive off the cliff. He purposely drove off.â€  Dharmesh Patel, 41, has pleaded not guilty to three counts of attempted murder. He is in custody without bail. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for June 12, at which time a judge will decide if there's enough evidence to move ahead with a trial.  Patel was driving his white 2021 Tesla Model Y along the Pacific Coast Highway south of San Francisco when the car plunged several hundred feet off the cliff at Devilâ€™s Slide. Firefighters had to cut the family out of the wreckage.  The warrant affidavit includes an interview with Patel while he was recovering from major lower body injuries. In the interview, he said his wife was irritated shortly before the plunge off the cliff because she didn't want to stop at his brother's house in San Mateo County before making their drive home to the Los Angeles area, the Chronicle reported.  He said he was not really depressed but that he felt down because times were bad in the world, according to the affidavit.  "Asked if he felt suicidal, he said, â€˜You know, not like a plan, not usually,â€™" the affidavit said.

Earlier this year, Steve Waye did an internet search for â€œgay eventsâ€ and his zip code in Wells River.  â€œI used to live in a big city, so there were a hundred returns for that search,â€ he said. â€œBut not anymore.â€  Waye left Oakland, California a few years ago to escape the wildfires and smoke. In Vermont he was looking "to make contact with actual people instead of app people," he said.  Thatâ€™s how he ended up playing UNO and listening to Radiohead on a Friday night at Vittles House of Brews this winter.  "The first time we came, I met three new-to-me trans people, which feels like a miracle out here. Iâ€™m usually the only trans person in a room." Nikki Stevens, Bradford  The room was full of people. Sitting nearby were a couple professors from Dartmouth College, a local state representative, young farmers, and someone tabling for Planned Parenthood.  Itâ€™s the sort of scene Travis Gendron would have never encountered growing up in the area.  â€œIâ€™m sort of blown away right now by the amount of people [here],â€ he said.  Heâ€™s the co-owner of Vittles with his wife, Kendall Gendron. For half a year, they've been hosting these monthly events called â€œOut in Bradford.â€  â€œThis is the night that we are setting aside specifically for queer people and queer allies,â€ Kendall told me by phone. â€œYou canâ€™t walk through the door without knowing.â€  Lexi Krupp / Vermont Public Travis Gendron is the co-owner of Vittles. He grew up in Corinth and went to high school in Bradford. He said there wouldn't have been an event like this for the queer community back then.  So far, they've been a hit.  "The first time we came, I met three new-to-me trans people, which feels like a miracle out here," said Nikki Stevens, from Bradford, who was sitting with a group of friends. "Iâ€™m usually the only trans person in a room. So to see brand-new faces was quite a delight."  For Rebecca Joy Henrietta White, who also grew up in the area, the event is just as significant for the people who arenâ€™t there.  "Itâ€™s also important for the community to see," she said. "We can integrate and peacefully coexist, because it hasnâ€™t always felt like that."  Lexi Krupp / Vermont Public Vittles has been hosting a monthly event called "Out in Bradford" for the past six months.  Not everyone has loved what the coffee shop is doing . Earlier this year, the pride flag hanging outside was stolen. They still get the occasional angry email.  But it's not something the owners dwell on. For them, holding the monthly gatherings feels like a responsibility.  "Almost like a moral obligation," Kendall Gendron said. "You canâ€™t get that experience anywhere else within like a 30-, 50-mile radius."  _  Lexi Krupp is a corps member with Report for America, a nonprofit national service program that places journalists in local newsrooms to report on under-covered issues and regions.

Get In-Depth Insights and Exclusive Content Delivered Direct to You.  Makeup legend Bobbi Brownâ€™s Jones Road Beauty opens its new East Hampton store on Wednesday, May 17.  The new store, located at 55 Main Street, is the first on Long Island for the brand though Brown has long had a home in the Hamptons.  â€œI love to work where I live and really love living in Sag Harbor. Itâ€™s so relaxed,â€ Brown tells Behind The Hedges.  In fact, her new companyâ€™s name comes right from East Hampton.  â€œWe had worked with some copywriters and were racking our brains on the name for weeks and nothing was sticking,â€ Brown remembers.  â€œThen one day, my husband and I were driving to the Hamptons and I was navigating. I looked down and there it was on the Waze navigation app: Jones Road. I immediately loved the name and so did my husband and the team. We checked to see if it was available and it was, so the brand became Jones Road. Iâ€™m also obsessed with all things British so I liked that it sounds like a bespoke UK brand.â€  Jones Road was created with the philosophy that the world doesnâ€™t need more beauty products but instead needs better beauty products. The clean, high-grade formulations are meant to work with every skin type and tone and are simple to use.  â€œIâ€™m a makeup artist and I love formulating and creating new products,â€ explains Brown, who left her well-known namesake company in 2016 (EstÃ©e Lauder bought the company in 1995 and Brown stayed on with the company for nearly two decades. She is no longer affiliated or associated with Bobbi Brown Cosmetics or Bobbi Brown branded products).  â€œWhen I started working on Jones Road, I was thinking about what I wanted and what I know other women wanted because they were asking me on my social media channels. I was focused on creating a clean beauty brand that over-delivered on my expectations and Jones Road is it: an edited indispensable collection of clean, high-grade formulations designed for all ages, skin types and skin tones.â€  Jones Road launched in 2020 amid the COVID-19 pandemic as a direct-to-consumer cosmetics line. The flagship store opened in Montclair, New Jersey, where Brown and her husband also reside, in 2021 and there is also a store in Greenwich Village in Manhattan.  â€œWhen someone is wearing Jones Road, I want them to feel like themselves on their best day. The most powerful beauty product is self-confidence. I want our customers to feel good in their own skin, with just the right amount of makeup,â€ Brown says.  Brown says she set out to create the makeup equivalent of a Swiss Army Knife, â€œproducts that were clean, easy to use and multi-purpose that worked for any skin type or skin tone.â€ Many of the products fit that description, but her favorite is the Miracle Balm, â€œa one-of-a-kind game-changing product.â€ Itâ€™s now available in nine shades.  â€œOn my social channels, I do a lot of educational content about Miracle Balm to show consumers how to use it. You use your fingers to press into the balm, breaking the seal so all the emollients mix into the formula. Then, you just rub your fingers together and pat the Miracle Balm onto your cheeks and/or lips (for a subtle glow and to add luminosity). It makes you instantly look better,â€ she says.  â€œThe Jones Road aesthetic â€” cool, clean beauty â€” aligns perfectly with the Hamptons vibe,â€ Brown says. â€œItâ€™s hard to find the perfect space so when we saw this location open up, we jumped on it. We love the neighborhood, itâ€™s one of my favorite alleyways. Weâ€™re so looking forward to opening our doors.â€  Several launches are planned this month. Jones Road recently released a lab sample of its first fragrance called â€œShowerâ€ and it sold out within 48 hours â€“ not to worry, though, Brown says it will be back on the shelves this fall. Jones Road is also introducing a collection of tinted powders later this month, just in time for the summer.  For Memorial Day weekend, the brand is releasing a limited-edition set of mini Miracle Balms â€œthat I think will be gone in days,â€ Brown says. â€œWe are so excited to launch a new bronzer this June.â€  Email [email protected] with further comments, questions, or tips. Follow Behind The Hedges on Twitter, Instagram and Facebook.

Weather Alert  ...OZONE HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR THE TUCSON METRO AREA ON FRIDAY... The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued an Ozone High Pollution Advisory for the Tucson Metro area on Friday. This means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing ozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates. Ozone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties for children, older adults, as well as persons with respiratory problems. A decrease in physical activity is recommended. You are urged to car pool, telecommute, or use mass transit. The use of gasoline-powered equipment should be reduced or done late in the day. For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/tucson or call 602- 771-2300.

Kerry Irving with Max wearing his PDSA Order of Merit  A man who has raised thousands of pounds for charities and upped the profile of the town is to become the first person to be given the freedom of Keswick.  The town council has agreed to give Kerry Irving, who has a massive global following online for his escapades with his spaniels, the highest order of merit the local authority can give.  The Freedom of the Town is given to someone who is, in the opinion of the council, a person of distinction and has rendered eminent services to the local area.  There is no material honour or special privilege attached, although historically there was and these are now symbolic.  He will be bestowed with the honour at a special ceremony to be held at Hope Park â€“ the home of the statue of Mr Irvingâ€™s beloved spaniel Max â€“ on Friday May 26 at 1.30pm.  Max died last year but has left a huge legacy behind. The popular dog was awarded the animal equivalent of an OBE â€“ the PDSA Order of Merit â€“ and raised hundreds of thousands of pounds for charities and supported people through the Covid-19 pandemic through social media updates of adventures with Mr Irving in the Lake District.  Mr Irving credits Max for turning his life around after a traffic collision left him with chronic pain and unable to walk as well as mental health issues.  There will be a short council meeting at the park to confirm that the authority will confer the honour, and then the mayor, Cllr Steve Harwood, will present Mr Irving with the Freedom Scroll before a short speech is delivered.  Council clerk Vivien Little said the honour was being conferred on Mr Irving because he had raised the profile of the town so much, had done incredible work for charity and for Hope Park.  He had also done a huge amount to bring mental health issues to the forefront nationally.

His Eminence Archbishop Elpidophoros  Archpastoral Exhortation to the Metropolis of New Jersey Clergy Laity Assembly and Philoptochos Convention  May 15, 2023  The Venetian â€“ Garfield, New Jersey  Your Grace, Bishop Apostolos of Medeia,  Father Christoforos Oikonomidis, Chancellor of the Metropolis,  Father George Chioros, President of Clergy Syndesmos,  Archon Peter Arbes, Vice Chair of the Metropolitan Council,  Mrs. Eleni Constantinides, of the Metropolis Philoptochos,  Reverend Fathers,  Esteemed Archons of the Ecumenical Patriarchate,  Honored Members of Leadership 100,  Dear Sisters of the Metropolis Philoptochos,  Esteemed Delegates to the Clergy Laity Assembly,  Beloved Brothers and Sisters in Christ,  Î§ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„á½¸Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ½Î­ÏƒÏ„Î·!  Christ is Risen!  Once again we are assembled for the Clergy Laity Assembly of the Holy Metropolis of New Jersey. I have just returned from a pilgrimage to the Patriarchate of Alexandria, and I would share some of the inspiration that all of the pilgrims â€“ received, from His Beatitude Patriarch Theodore, from the faithful clergy, and the lay leaders we encountered.  For this ancient and venerable Church â€“ founded by the Apostle and Evangelist Mark himself, has embraced a healthy and positive zeal for mission throughout Africa, despite the many and arduous challenges She faces.  As we engage today on behalf of our Metropolis, with many reports and useful information, I will uphold the example of our Alexandrian brethren, to inspire our labors to even greater heights. They serve an entire continent, and for their fidelity to the canonical order of the Church, they have endured an uncanonical invasion of their rightful ecclesiastical domain by the Russian Church. This unfortunate state of affairs speaks to the righteousness of the Alexandrian cause; for they suffer for standing with our Most Holy Ecumenical Patriarchate, by supporting the independence and autocephaly of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine. Against such pressures, our problems cannot loom very large, for we are blessed to live in a country of freedom and prosperity. And the Metropolis of New Jersey is a network of successful communities who receive great benefits, merely by being American.  Therefore, today as we consider all the items on our agenda, I want all of us to keep our Alexandrian brothers and sisters in mind. They do not allow a paucity of resources to keep them from ministry. They not only make do with what they have, they multiply the effects of their ministries through their love and devotion. They take the little, and they turn it into the great. Much like our Lord Jesus Christ did when He fed the Five Thousand.  Everyone remembers the story of the Feeding of the Five Thousand, the only miracle to occur in all Four Gospels. There are two ways to look at it. First, we can easily say that for the Lord, Who created Heaven and Earth, to multiply five loaves and two fishes to feed the thousands, would have surely have been simple. But there is another way to think about this miracle.  Perhaps, when the young boy offered all that he had â€“ and I note here the detail from the Gospel of John, that the boyâ€™s loaves were of the poorest quality â€“ perhaps the people who witnessed his pure offering were inspired. Perhaps many of those thousands had brought food with them, that day, but were keeping it hidden only for themselves. When they witnessed the generosity, and the Lordâ€™s blessing, their hearts were freed to be generous with others. I am not saying that one version is better or worse than the other. But I think you will all agree with me. We can consider them both miracles.  Therefore, when I consider the wonders of community building, of missionary activity, and all the superb efforts of the Patriarchate of Alexandria on behalf of all Africa, I see a similar miracle. They are doing so very much with so very little. And here in the God-saved Metropolis of New Jersey, we are no different, except our resources are certainly more abundant. What is needed is to maintain and augment our generosity of spirit, our capacities to love and forgive, our commitment to philanthropy and compassion. The blessings of this Metropolis are self-evident: outstanding clergy and lay leadership, established communities, and a desire to live the Gospel.  Let us then, my beloved sisters and brothers in the Risen Lord, take inspiration from our brethren across the sea. And let us apply ourselves at every stage of Church life with the same passion and the energy that is transforming Africa.  We have every advantage. We have every opportunity. With Godâ€™s help, and through the intercessions of His Holy Mother and those of the Metropolisâ€™ heavenly patron, Saint John Chrysostom, we shall succeed.  Î§ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„á½¸Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ½Î­ÏƒÏ„Î·!

Angel, an 11-year-old girl with Cloves Syndrome, may have a new lease on life thanks to a miracle dr  An 11-year-old girl named Angel with a rare disorder called Cloves Syndrome is hoping a miracle drug could massively improve her quality of life. Her feet have grown so large that she requires a wheelchair and is unable to walk. The condition has caused significant pain and led doctors to consider amputating both of her feet in 2019.  â€˜Disease-resistantâ€™ tomato varieties to grow at home, according to an expert  However, the operation was deemed too risky. Angel had limited options until Moira Kelly, an Australian humanitarian worker and the founder of the Creating Hope Foundation, became involved in her case.  Angel was born in Pakistan and brought to Australia in 2017 for medical treatment.  The Daily Star reports that after researching Cloves Syndrome, Ms Kelly discovered a report published in France about the use of Alpelisib, often used as a treatment for breast cancer, to combat the disease.  Ms Kelly then took Angel to Paris for an assessment, which found the youngster would be eligible to take the medication. They had a ball.  Zoe Milsom and her beloved Frenchie â€œfur babyâ€ got pregnant at the same time. Now, the mom is recalling the thrilling experience.  Milsom, 29, is already mom to Leon, 13. She and her beau, Paul, got engaged in May 2020, eager to see their family grow.  But an ectopic pregnancy and a diagnosis of polycystic ovary syndrome, which can affect fertility, dashed her hopes of a baby.  A human one, that is.  While Zoe Milsom was pregnant, Beau curled up on her belly and rarely left her side. Jam Press  Milsom and Beau experienced losses â€” a void that baby Alfie helped fill. Jam Press  The couple soon welcomed Beau, the French bulldog, into their home as their beloved â€œfur baby.â€  â€œShe was the second child I never had and quickly became one of the family, going on holidays and any trips with us,â€ Milsom told Jam Press.  Her 2022 pregnancy, then, came as quite the shock, as did Beauâ€™s seven months later.  â€œI couldnâ€™t believe we were going to be mommies together,â€ Milsom gushed.  For Milsom, Alfie was a miracle after experiencing an ectopic pregnancy and believing sheâ€™d never conceive another child naturally. Jam Press  While the couple werenâ€™t â€œvery happyâ€ about their pupâ€™s pregnancy because it â€œdefinitely wasnâ€™t the right time,â€ they welcomed the challenge.  â€œI was very excited, as the feeling of being a mom is amazing,â€ she continued. â€œItâ€™s a new life being brought into the world â€” or in her case, nine â€” and we planned on keeping at least one puppy for her to have a motherly bond with.â€  Milsom couldnâ€™t wait to see how Beau interacted with Alfie, who was born in November 2022, after the pup cozied up to her belly for nine months.  Two weeks after Alfie arrived, Beau gave birth to a litter of nine, but none of them survived due to complications from an infection.  Beau and Alfie are best buds now. Jam Press  â€œI understood her pain having lost a baby of my own,â€ Milsom said, recalling how forlorn Beau appeared as she moped around the house. â€œI couldnâ€™t stop crying, and I tried all I could to save them, but nothing worked.  â€œI felt like I had let my little girl down, as she had gone through all of that for nothing â€” it was heartbreaking,â€ she added.  While Beau has since been spayed, her bond with little Alfie is â€œamazing.â€  â€œItâ€™s amazing seeing them together, as she protects him with her mothering instincts and sees him as one of her own,â€ Milsom said of her â€œmiracles.â€  â€œI look at them both everyday, and my eyes fill with tears because of how in love and proud I am of my two little babies,â€ said Milsom. Jam Press  When Alfie cries, Beau attempts to soothe him by licking his face. Jam Press  When Alfie cries, Beau soothingly licks his face and often â€œfalls asleep with him at night.â€  Where Beau filled a void for Milsom, Alfie is doing the same for the Frenchie.  â€œIâ€™m so grateful for both of them, theyâ€™re miracles,â€ Milsom said.  â€œI look at them both everyday, and my eyes fill with tears because of how in love and proud I am of my two little babies.â€

Western New York know-how and creativity played a big role in $550 million rehab of iconic Olympic sites.  LAKE PLACID, N.Y. â€” WNY has played a huge role in celebrating the history and preserving the future of one of New York State's most iconic recreational areas, the site of two Olympic games, Lake Placid.  In February of 2020, Daybreak took you up for the start of what was then a $100 million renovation, but ultimately the project grew to a $550 million overhaul spanning several years, modernizing 6 different venues (five in the Adirondacks and one in the Catskills) as well as the construction of a new administration building for the Olympic Regional Development Authority in Lake Placid. Now that it is complete, the upgrades are getting high marks.  At this year's Miracle On Ice fantasy camp, the men behind the miracle, like former Sabres' captain, Mike Ramsey, got their first peak at the renovated complex.  "It's a wonderful town, it's a pretty cool place to visit and obviously it holds a pretty special place in my heart," Ramsey said.  This project wasn't just a fresh coat of paint and new furniture, it was a restoration and reimagining of all of the sites, bringing them back to international competition standards, and beyond. Among the projects, Whiteface, Belleayre & Gore Mountains received updates to snowmaking, electrical, lodge, lift improvements or replacements, and E-groomers.  At the Olympic Jumping Complex they built Intervales Lodge, added new LED lighting, elevated deck, frost rails and in-run reinforcements, elevator replacement, gondola, and summer surfaces. It is now the only facility in North America certified for summer and winter training and competition. At the Olympic Center they added LED lighting, 1932 and 1980 arenas modernization, Oval modernization, refrigeration plant, e-zamboniâ€™s, a new public space called Miracle Plaza, and a brand new Lake Placid and Olympic Museum.  Among the biggest investments was at Mt. Van Hoevenberg, where they built a new 55,000 square foot building called the Mountain Pass Lodge, along with new snowmaking, electrical improvements, a biathlon stadium, e-groomer, roller loops and roadway paving, Nordic competition trails, and even a mountain coaster. The facility also features the nation's only indoor refrigerated bobsled and luge start track.  All of this work, has a strong Queen City footprint, beginning with the original architectural design work, done by the Buffalo team of CannonDesign. Jamie Graham says it is a project that will stay with her.  "It's a once in a lifetime project. A project with so much history. It was really great just to see that from beginning all the way through the end and when it opened back up."  Buffalo's Hadley Exhibits brought much of that work to life, in one of the new centerpieces, the Olympic museum.  "It was a lot to start with and I never really thought about 1932. There was a whole 'nother game" company president Ted Johnson. He said this was definitely a project of passion said.  "It was such an emotional connection, remembering where I was for the miracle on ice. My mother never showed emotion and there she is and she's crying and I'll never forget that."  Another WNY connection came with the pennants on the wall in the museum. The recreations are the handy work of Buffalo's own Oxford Pennant.  There is history all around, but the mission here was to celebrate that history and replace the artifacts that were still in use, like the mechanics in the Olympic Center's refrigeration plant, that supports the ice surfaces of three indoor rinks and the outdoor speed skating oval. It was the same system that was in use when Herb Brooks' team won gold, and Eric Heiden took home 5 gold medals during the 1980 games.  Facilities Superintendent Eric Martin, a Rochester native, says he was having to get very creative to even keep things going.  "It was old and dated. I was finding parts on eBay, hot-wiring things here and there, the parts just weren't available," Martin said.  Olympic Center General Manager Chadd Cassidy, who grew up right next door to the center, says this is about keeping the facilities sustainable for the next 50 years or more.  "We can do everything that we did before, but we do it a lot better," Cassidy said.

Her Story, Her Way  CYNTHIA DENISE â€œFOOTSIEâ€ TRAVIS  The Lord is nigh and to them that are of a broken heart, And saveth such as be of a contrite spirit. Psalms 34: 18 KJV  Today we celebrate the life of our beloved Cynthia Denise â€œFootsieâ€ Travis, a wonderful daughter, loving mother and grandmother, a beautiful sister, aunt, Godmother, cousin and friend.  On May 7th, 2023, as the sun begin to set, Cynthia transitioned from this Earthly Realm in the comforts of her home in Benton Harbor, Michigan. She was employed by JVIS Manufacturing, Benton Harbor Michigan for several years where she worked in numerous capacities.  Cynthia graced the world with her presence on November 11, 1960, to the proud parents of Delores Carter Travis and Bill Robinson in Berrien Center, Michigan. She was coined with the nickname â€œFootsieâ€ by a family friend. She was short in stature, yet she had the heart of a giant.  Cynthia accepted Christ as her personal savior at an early age under the spiritual guidance of Reverend C. L. Woodson at Pleasant Grove Missionary Baptist Church, where she was a member of the youth choir and was crowned many times as the Tom Thumb Queen. She enjoyed spending time with family and friends and she never met a stranger.  Cynthia received her formal education in the Benton Harbor Area Schools District and was a proud graduate of the Benton Harbor High School class of 1978 in which she remained a faithful member.  Cynthia was formerly employed at Mercy Hospital as a Pharmacy Tech (her 1st job), the Manager of Burger King for many years, and Wollin Products where she received her miracle child.  Upon graduation, Cynthia enlisted in the United States Army where she proudly served as PFC Cynthia Denise Travis, and upon completion of her tour she became a member of the Michigan Army National Guard where she served for many years. She would often celebrate with fellow soldiers and Captain Newton, whom she loved and respected dearly.  In 1986 she married the love of her life, Mr. Leonard Brock, and to this union a precious little girl was born whom they affectionately named Lenesha Denise.  Cynthia continued living life her way and as graduation was drawing near for Lenesha, she showed us once again that her story would be told her way. To all of our surprise Cynthia and Eddie French welcomed a miracle, literally, and what better way to express their gratitude as the name of their new bundle of joy, their baby girl, Miracle Denise Delores Travis. A special thank you to God and an honor to her Mother and Miracleâ€™s grandmother, the late Mrs. Delores Carter.  Cynthia loved her girls Lenesha and Miracle, with her whole heart and adored her grandchildren Dontrall, DeAndre, Jamylah and Jaylen.  Cynthia was an awesome sister to all of her siblings and the bond she shared with each of them was established at an early age, as Mama Delores made sure of that.  Cynthia enjoyed life and lived it unapologetically. She told her story, her way.  Cynthia would often say that â€œshe was tired and Iâ€™m going to go lay downâ€ and in true â€œFootsieâ€ fashion, this time she meant it. Her favorite song in which she sang as a child was â€œI Shall Wear A Crownâ€. It is our prayer that our Lord and Saviour heard her plea.  Our dearly beloved Cynthia Denise, we will cherish the many memories and hold dear in our hearts your love and kindred spirit, youâ€™re free.  She leaves precious memories to be cherished in the hearts of her daughters: Lenesha Travis and Miracle Travis of Benton Harbor, MI and Gwendolyn Williams Wallace of Indianapolis, IN. Sons, Dontril (Shaquita) Williams of Indianapolis, IN, David Williams and Leonard Williams of Indianapolis, IN, Darius Williams and DeMarko Williams of Kalamazoo, MI. Grandchildren, Dontrall Bell, Grand Rapids, MI, Deâ€™Andre Travis, Jaylen Sanders, and Jaâ€™mylah Sanders, Benton Harbor, MI. Sisters, Mary Travis, Eleanor Carter, LaVerne (Kevin) White, Rita Travis-Broadway, and Carolyn Travis of Benton Harbor, MI. Annette Banda, Milwaukee, WI and Barbara Fambro, Cleveland, OH. Brothers, Victor (Armentha) Williford, Benton Harbor, MI, Demetrius Carter, Detroit, MI, Robert Carter, Decatur, IL, and Stanley Robinson, Cleveland, OH. Her Godchildren, Deshayila Williams Hill, Qurvon and Coreon Williams of Benton Harbor, MI. Special friends Leonard Brock, of Detroit, MI, and Eddie French of Benton Harbor, MI. Godmotherâ€™s Mrs. Addie Jenkins and Mrs. Georgia â€œBaylouâ€ Willis. Godbrothers Omar (Felicia) Boyd of Indianapolis, IN, Stevie Viel and Jerry Jenkins, and God sisters Yolanda Jones, Patricia Malone, Eula Taylor, and Wanda Kaye Jenkins of Benton Harbor, MI. Life-long best friends Sherry Archibald (Patrick) Hill, Sabrina Guidry, Laddy (Larry) Edwards, and Denise â€œPigâ€ Jones.  Cynthia is preceded in death by her Mother, Delores Carter, Fathers Bill Robinson, Joe Travis and Walter Carter, granddaughter Shakiya Smith and Grandparents Katherine Steucy and Mary Alexander, niece Tiffany Carter, and great nephew Tajâ€™ Carter.
