OF COURSE, MY DAILY REMINDER IS MY CHILD, TAYLOR, USING HER UNIQUE DELIVERY EXPERIENCE TO HELP OTHERS SOON TO BE MOMS. TODAY, SHEâ€™S NOW A NURSE AT THE VERY HOSPITAL WHERE SHE GAVE BIRTH AT NORMAN REGIONAL HOSPITAL. ITâ€™S DEFINITELY COME FULL CIRCLE. I WORK IN LABOR AND DELIVERY, WHICH I ABSOLUTELY LOVE. IN FACT, SHE EVEN WORKS WITH THAT SAME DOCTOR WHO DELIVERED BRADEN. SHE DIDNâ€™T REALIZE WHO I WAS FOR A WHILE BECAUSE I NEVER TOLD HER. AND THEN ONE DAY SHE JUST WALKS UP TO ME AND SHEâ€™S LIKE, YOUâ€™RE SHAYLA, ARENâ€™T YOU? AND I WAS LIKE, YEAH. AND SO SHE STARTS SHOWING ME PICTURES THAT SHE HAD FROM THE HOSPITAL AND STUFF. On the website of La RazÃ³n del Istmo, dedicated to citizensâ€™ reflections, lawyer and academician Jorge Gonzalez recalled the benefits of this free service program, which resulted from an agreement signed on March 15, 2007.  The mission, a great work of solidarity, according to the writer, began in the western province of Veraguas, as it was a strategic territory that facilitated access to the deep country as well as to the transit zone and the capital.  Operation Miracle allowed performing approximately 50,000 eye surgeries and its scope of attention covered 75,000 people in total, Gonzalez said.  Many of the surgeries were performed in Panama and some in Cuba.  Among the main diseases that were treated were cataracts, glaucoma, retinal damage and vision disorders resulting from diabetes, he added.  In 2009, the political science graduate said, the newly elected government at the time (referring to the Ricardo Martinelli administration) decided, without any consultations, to terminate Operation Miracle, leaving 69,000 people pending on ophthalmologic services.  After highlighting the role of Cuban physicians in other missions in Panama, such as in 2020 and 2021, when members of the Henry Reeve International Brigade collaborated in the fight against Covid-19, Gonzalez pointed out that the demand for the return of Operation Miracle is not aimed at replacing Panamanian professionals, as he is in favor of deeply social ideas.  Science and technology, works of human accumulation, must be at the service of the people, the analyst remarked.  jg/abo/mem/ga

The Miracle Project - a groundbreaking fully inclusive neurodiverse theater, film, social skills, and expressive arts program for individuals with autism and all abilities - is celebrating its 18th birthday in grand style with two, joyous, back-to-back, family-friendly matinees spotlighting a neurodiverse cast of Miracle Project performers ages 5 to 65 in an array of musical, sketch comedy, and improv performances, and more on Sunday, May 28, 2023, at 2 pm and 4:30 pm, at the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts' Lovelace Studio Theater. The artists will share their unique voices, talents, and stories in a festive program that also honors Miracle Project Founder Elaine Hall for her tireless and selfless efforts to enhance the lives of the neurodiverse community and their families through the arts.  This inclusive event, which includes a Q&A with participants as well, is open to audience members of all ages and abilities. ASL interpretation and Audio Description will be provided. Each show is capped by a post-performance reception for ticket holders held in The Wallis' Wells Family Education Courtyard.  The celebration also feature the world premiere of The Miracle Project Takes the Cake, an original production created with and starring children, teens, and young adults on the autism spectrum, those with and without disabilities, and their peers. During the interactive and improvised mystery, told in two parts, performers will task audience members with cracking the case of a harrowing cake heist. Stay for both shows to get to the bottom of this "whodunnit" mystery!  The Miracle Project and its 18th Birthday Celebration is part of this year's Take Action For Mental Health LA County campaign, a roster of events occurring county-wide during Mental Health Awareness Month, sponsored by the Los Angeles County Department of Mental Health (LACDMH) and the California Mental Health Services Authority (CalMHSA). Additional support for The Miracle Project Takes the Cake has also been provided by the California Arts Council (CAC) and the Los Angeles Trial Lawyers' Charities (LATLC).  Tickets, $25/show or $45 for both shows, are available at https://cloud.broadwayworld.com/rec/ticketclick.cfm?fromlink=2242758Â®id=9&articlelink=https%3A%2F%2Fthewallis.org%2Fshow-details%2Fthe-miracle-project-takes-the-cake?utm_source=BWW2022&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=article&utm_content=bottombuybutton1.

â€œYou got to put a lot of cheese on it didnâ€™t you,â€ said mom Stephanie Calkins to her children Tuesday.  She and her children Henry and Margot are reliving their recent trip to a Queen Creek Costco, one that was anything but ordinary.  The siblings were chosen by Phoenix Childrenâ€™s as fundraising ambassadors for the hospital's latest charity drive.  â€œItâ€™s something that they get to do that is associated with Phoenix Childrenâ€™s, thatâ€™s not negative, thatâ€™s not scary, thatâ€™s fun,â€ said Calkins.  Seven-year-old Henry was born with a rare autoimmune disease thatâ€™s forced him to spend much of his life in and out of the hospital. It's a genetic condition that can cause his own immune system to attack itself.  His sister Margot was recently diagnosed with the same condition.  â€œHenryâ€™s life has drastically changed since heâ€™s moved to Phoenix Childrens,â€ explained Calkins.  Specialized medical care provided there has given both of her kids their lives back. But that care isnâ€™t cheap. It costs $2.7 million per day to operate Phoenix Childrenâ€™s, providing for nearly 270,000 patients each year.  â€œAll those different programs need funding, and it truly makes a difference,â€ said Calkins.  Last week, Henry and Margot were sent to the Queen Creek Costco with a job to do.  As honorary employees, name tags and all, they checked receipts and processed returns.  The siblings slipped on hairnets and made pizza and decorated cakes, all while urging customers to make a small donation. During the month of May, those donations are matched by Costco, hoping to raise more than a million dollars.  â€œHenry and Margot were just like jumping around, you could see how excited they were, they were telling them thank you, and telling them what theyâ€™ve been through, and why it meant so much,â€ said Calkins. â€œA lot of the employees seemed to be really passionate about talking to customers about donating after that.â€  Itâ€™s clear from the photos that the kids' visit left an incredible impression, giving employees all the motivation they needed to hit their goals and beyond.  For Calkins, the hundreds of paper balloons hanging from the wall representing each donation sent her family and others like it a powerful message from the community.  "That's why we love where we live, they are always here for us," said Calkins. â€œGet over to your local Costco and donate because you are changing a child's life.â€

OPINION:  Before Elon Musk acquired Twitter and even more often following the transaction, the obituary for the social media giant has been written many times. I wrote a few myself. The Big Tech media corporation had essentially killed itself before Mr. Musk took control.  As the sink-carrying billionaire walked into Twitter headquarters (with a wallet $44 billion lighter) last October, the home base for reporters and influencers was little more than a boring left-wing echo chamber.  While Mr. Musk demonstrates the ability to run successful businesses (the worldâ€™s wealthiest people often do), many thought he was too late to save Twitter. The censorship, shadow banning and so-called fact-checking were killing the marketplace of ideas. It drove many users, including me, away.  Many business-saving initiatives are being pursued at Twitter â€” selling blue checks and subscriptions and sharing ad revenue, to name a few â€” but nothing seems to be accelerating the successful turnaround that free speech advocates so desperately want to see. While it was a lot of fun to see NPR called state-run media, the business of Twitter still seems to be on thin ice.  The Big Tech media corporationsâ€™ legacy of going beyond being just communication mediums is a tough one to overcome. These entities are writing, editing and controlling stories with little regard for truth or actual events. Big Tech is frustrating and disappointing us, but itâ€™s eerily similar to what traditional news outlets have been doing for years.  We know that embracing â€œwokeâ€ culture at the expense of free speech ultimately fails, but can it be stopped in time for a turnaround? Hopefully, Mr. Musk will refrain from exercising his editing skills and remain a free speech absolutist.  Mr. Musk promised a change. He knew open-minded people are hungry for a fair platform that welcomes all ideas and ignores cancel culture. But despite his best efforts, it seems it will take a miracle to turn Twitter around.  That miracle may be happening, however, now that Tucker Carlson announced he is taking his show to Twitter. This is a brilliant move, especially for a media personality particularly critical of the mainstream media, accusing them of bias and hypocrisy and questioning their commitment to free speech.  Within a few hours of Mr. Carlsonâ€™s announcement, his video had already reached an exponentially higher audience than anything in a Fox News leaderâ€™s wildest dream. His message about the critical value of free speech, truth-telling, and reporting the news without fear of censorship or editorial interference is a rallying cry bringing people together and surely a topic of discussion in traditional network boardrooms.  It doesnâ€™t cost much to be an independent journalist these days, but it costs a fortune to be a corporate one. Anyone with a smartphone, a web connection and ideas can find an audience. Producing a show for a television network, however, can be expensive due to the need for high-quality production equipment, studios and personnel. And the legal costs are surely prohibitive, because when you exercise free speech, some donâ€™t like what is being said.  As he brings his new show to Twitter, Mr. Carlson and the platform will surely be sued, repeatedly. But the Constitution is on his side. Protecting your free speech rights can cost a lot, especially when defending them in court. McCutcheon v. Federal Election Commission wasnâ€™t easy even back in 2014, but it was worth it.  Unlike traditional media outlets, Messrs. Carlson and Musk seem unafraid of the cultural fear of threatened boycotts, legal fees, jury awards, and settlements that cause journalists on the left and the right to think twice about expressing their points of view â€” and news executives outright preventing it.  News executives see the value of free speech falling below what it costs to be associated with retribution for opinionated or firebrand anchors. Simply put, the constitutional freedom at the heart of all the others costs them too much.  The good news for Mr. Carlson is that Mr. Musk already paid the $44 billion bill.  As traditional legacy media continues to lose credibility the same way Twitter was losing users before Mr. Musk took over, there is a glimmer of hope on the horizon â€” for Mr. Musk, for Mr. Carlson and for all of us.  Using Twitter to circumvent the restrictions, regulations and obstacles set up by traditional media networks is a genius move â€” and could be the miracle that saves Twitter. I know Iâ€™m going to give Twitter another try.  â€¢ Shaun McCutcheon is a free speech advocate, an Alabama-based electrical engineer, the founder of Multipolar, and the successful plaintiff in the 2014 Supreme Court case McCutcheon v. FEC.

David Guetta has shared a remix of Calvin Harrisâ€™ â€˜Miracleâ€™, featuring Ellie Goulding, which he debuted at Ultra Music Festival Miami in March. Listen to the track below.  The Future Rave-inspired remix earned a colossal reception on the festivalâ€™s mainstage, and spurred Guetta to release his take on the single. â€œIt started that day when I was just making my own version for Ultra,â€ he confirmed on his Instagram.  The French DJ and EDM kingpin is the latest to join the remix roster for the number one hit, following in the footsteps of the likes of Hardwell, Mau P, and Wilkinson.  The original â€™90s trance-inspired single, released back in March on Sony Music, marked the first joint track from Calvin Harris and Ellie Goulding in almost a decade, and was accompanied by a futuristic music video set in a desert landscape.  Speaking to Apple Music at the time, Harris said: â€œI've done the trancey-sounding things before, but I've never been this fast, so it feels good. When I was 14, it was '98, '99 â€“ for me it was kind of [a] formative trance and house era. I thought maybe I'll just try and recreate something that could be from back then.â€  Next month, David Guetta will kick off his weekly FUTURE RAVE residency at HÃ¯ Ibiza â€“ voted DJ Magâ€™s number 1 club two years running â€“ taking place every Friday from June 2nd, and featuring Dutch DJ Morten and James Hype for a selection of the dates.  David Guettaâ€™s remix of â€˜Miracleâ€™ is out now, listen to it below.

Ashlee Aurora has been a mom for more than 12 years.  However, it wasn't until April 24 that she gave birth to her first child.  "This is a new stage for us," Aurora, 33, said Thursday, her new son, Waylon, resting in her arms.  "We've never done the newborn stage before," she said. "It's all new. The lack of sleep is new. All of our kids, when we got them, were old enough they were sleeping through the night, so thatâ€™s new. But itâ€™s great. I love it. Definitely gives a whole new purpose."  Aurora was told at age 16 she would never conceive because she has polycystic ovary syndrome, which can cause infertility. Doctors said if she did conceive, she wouldn't be able to carry to full term.  She and her high school sweetheart husband, Justin Aurora, have been together for 16 years. They had accepted they would have to adopt or foster if they wanted to be parents. It just happened sooner than they could have imagined.  Their oldest kids, Justyce, 15, and Jacob, 14, came into their lives when she and Justin were still kids themselves.  Ashlee worked as a nanny in Post Falls when she and Justin were 20. The grandfather of the family told Ashlee he knew of an older couple who needed help raising two young kids and asked if she would meet them. They went to dinner with the family the next day.  "We met these two little spitfire toddlers who were super shy and quiet," Ashlee said.  The children came to the elderly couple, of no relation, from birth parents who were not capable of caring for them. Ashlee and Justin began watching them in 2010, and within a month the siblings were living with them. By 2012, the Auroras had legal guardianship of the siblings, although they still stay in touch with the older woman, who they consider a grandmother.  "We were still young and doing our own thing," Ashlee said. "I knew at some point I wanted to have kids some way. I always thought it would be cool to go to Indonesia and do a mission trip. But it all just kind of happened. It totally was a God thing. God arranged it how it was supposed to be."  She credits Justyce and Jacob for jump-starting their adult lives. They went from carefree young adults to grown-ups with the responsibility of caring for little ones who needed them.  "It changed a lot for us, but totally for the best," Ashlee said.  Before long, Bryson came along. He was 7 months old when the Auroras first fostered him. He was in and out with his birth family, but when he landed back in the system, they knew he was meant to be with them.  Bryson, now 10, entered their lives after Ashlee took foster care training.  "At the end of the class, they tell you how many kids are in foster care, and it broke my heart," Ashlee said. "So we agreed to do foster care. And we ended up with ... a houseful ever since," Justin said.  How do they do it?  "We're broke," Justin joked.  He works at Kaiser Aluminum; she works at Children's Village. They have their four children, plus a friend's daughter, Lily, who stays with them throughout the school year, and they provide respite for foster parents. Their doors are always open when a child is in need.  "We have a lot of support. Our families help us a lot," Ashlee said. "Justyce drives now, so that is really helpful."  Through years of being adoptive parents to children they adore, the Cataldo couple expected to be empty-nesters by their early 40s.  But, as the saying goes, expect the unexpected.  "In August, I had the day off and I woke up and I just had this weird feeling I should take a pregnancy test,â€ Ashlee said.  She convinced herself it was impossible, but when she jumped on social media, the first video she saw had a baby in it. Then the next one.  â€œI was like, â€˜OK God, if thereâ€™s four more videos of babies, Iâ€™ll take a pregnancy test.â€™ And the next six videos were all of babies. So I took a pregnancy test," she said. "At that time, I would have only been like three-and-a-half weeks. They all showed up super positive.â€  In disbelief, she sent a picture of the pregnancy test to her cousin, with whom she is incredibly close.  â€œI was like, â€˜Is this what I think it is? I think Iâ€™m crazy, I donâ€™t know,â€™ and she was like, â€˜Oh my gosh, Ashlee, thatâ€™s positive,'" Ashlee said. "It took a good two months before I really fully believed it."  â€œAnd how many pregnancy tests?â€ Justin chimed in with a grin.  "I took a lot of pregnancy tests," she said, smiling back.  Justin admitted he was excited after the initial shock wore off.  "Mostly because I thought I had it figured out, how the future was going," he said.  That first day was rough for both of them. Was this real? Would they miscarry?  "I've always prayed that I'm thankful I can't conceive if I'm not going to carry," Ashlee said. "Emotionally, I don't know how I would handle that. I've always been stressed about that."  Ashlee was most excited to tell the big kids, although Justyce knew before her parents knew she knew.  "She cheated and saw my prenatals (vitamins) in my purse," Ashlee said, beaming a smile at Justyce. "She was a sneaker."  "Before that, I saw your pregnancy test," Justyce responded, also smiling.  Jacob said he was excited to welcome home a baby brother.  "Iâ€™m a lot older than he is, so it will just be cool,â€ he said. â€œIt didnâ€™t feel real at first.â€  "At first I was like, thatâ€™s so weird,'" Justyce said. â€œThen I thought it was really cool. Iâ€™m really happy.â€  â€œFor now, Iâ€™m fine with him,â€ Bryson said. â€œHeâ€™s going to start crawling and get in my room. The No. 1 thing off limits â€” my books.â€  For Ashlee, foster care is near to her heart. She said she always knew at some point she wanted to adopt through foster care, because she wasn't supposed to be able to have kids.  "Justin's just really good at going with the flow, and letting me bring lots of kids home," she said with a laugh.  Although they have a miraculous new addition, they have been loving parents for a long time. That love will only continue to grow.  "Our kids are all our kids," Ashlee said.

Newborn Carol Zaslowâ€™s chances were slim-to-none. Born at Cedars-Sinai three months premature on Dec. 6, 1945, the infant weighed just 14 ounces. The odds of her survival were 1 in 50,000.  Carolâ€™s doctors provided her with breastmilk via an eyedropper. After a few weeks, the eyedropper was replaced with a feeding tube. The liquid nutrition, coupled with the Jewish hospitalâ€™s incubators for preterm infants as well as skilled obstetricians trained in the latest scientific advances, allowed the fragile baby to beat the odds.  Carol not only survivedâ€”she thrived. The â€œmiracle babyâ€ grew up in Westwood, graduated from USC with a triple major in English, social services and education and went on to start a family with her husband, David Zaslow. They had two daughters, Tracy and Carrie, both of whom became doctors, crediting their mom for inspiring their respective career paths. Tracy is a primary care sports medicine physician in Los Angeles, and Carrie is an ophthalmologist in New York.  Coinciding with Motherâ€™s Day, Cedars-Sinai recently published an article about their former patient. The medical center said Carolâ€™s long life was centered on family and service. She spent several years as a kindergarten and first grade teacher in the Inglewood Unified School District before becoming a stay-at-home mom. Believing helping others was fundamental to a fulfilling life, she started a D.A.R.E. program at her daughtersâ€™ elementary school, served as a Brownie troop leader and was elected to the board of a nonprofit literary arts organization.  In her third act, Carol, an empty nester, became a published childrenâ€™s author, co-writing an award-winning series of books called â€œLittle Kids do BIG Things.â€  Last year, Carol was admitted to Cedars-Sinai for mitral valve regurgitation, a progressive heart-valve disease. She was readmitted several weeks later due to surgical complications. On June 10, 2022, she passed away.  Carol believed happy, healthy kids become compassionate and engaged adultsâ€”an outlook that informed her lifeâ€™s choices. To honor that legacy, while showing appreciation to the hospital that always felt like family, the Zaslows, who are Jewish, recently launched the Carol Zaslow Memorial Fund, which supports pediatric research at Cedars-Sinai Guerin Childrenâ€™s.  As of press time, the campaign had raised more than $170,000 of its $200,000 goal.  â€œDriven by the idea that investing in childrenâ€™s health is so critical because they are tomorrowâ€™s adults, and understanding pediatric research has always been underfunded, our family has decided that the Carol Zaslow Memorial Fund will be dedicated to furthering pediatric research to be able to maximally impact lives for generations to come,â€ the family wrote on Carolâ€™s memorial page.  This past weekend marked Carolâ€™s daughtersâ€™ first Motherâ€™s Day without their dearest mom, the woman who at birth defied all medical expectations and went on to live a long and meaningful life. In interviews with Cedars-Sinai, the Zaslows discussed the various ways they remembered Carol, a wife, mother and grandmother.  â€œMaybe Iâ€™ll make her famous lemon Bundt cake, and I definitely will set aside some time to read a book,â€ Carrie said. â€œMy mom loved to read.â€  Tracyâ€™s Motherâ€™s Day plans included being â€œtogether with family and sharing our favorite memories of her.â€ One of those memories involved when Carol was in the hospital last year. â€œIâ€™ll never forget her radiant smile when her two granddaughters made a surprise visit and showered their grammie with big hugs,â€ Tracy told Cedars-Sinai.  For Carolâ€™s husband, David, Motherâ€™s Day was an opportunity to reflect on how â€œblessed [he was] to find such a wonderful, caring, kind woman to be my wife,â€ he said. â€œCarol truly was a miracle baby, and that blessing led to our wonderful, very accomplished daughters who were blessed with their own childrenâ€”our five happy, healthy, bright grandchildren who bring so much joy. The odds were stacked against Carol, but look at the legacy she left.â€

This is a carousel. Use Next and Previous buttons to navigate  A Houston residentâ€™s recovery after a severe stroke is being described as â€œa miracleâ€ by his wife and his surgeon.  A Sunday in January that began with lunch out with friends took a turn for the worse later that night when 42-year-old Jeremy Simmons collapsed and fell unconscious in his home.  His wife Laura Simmons called 911 and Jeremy was rushed to HCA Houston Healthcare North Cypress hospital. A CT scan showed he had a stroke, four brain aneurysms and excessive bleeding to the brain.  INSIDER NEWSLETTER: Must-read stories and news to know from the Cy-Fair area  Laura said the only signs before his collapse were a headache and nausea, but they just thought it could be food poisoning.  Jeremy was transported to the hospitalâ€™s sister facility, HCA Houston Healthcare Northwest, which has a Level 2 Trauma Center.  Laura said the night was a blur. She worried about the effect an event like this might have on their five-year-old daughter.  â€œOur entire world just turned upside down in a split second. So, I just really wanted some normalcy for her,â€ Laura said.  The family tried to keep her routine as normal as possible.  SURPRISE CELEBRATION: Spring-area hospital throws surprise birthday party for 62-year-old recovering from tear in heart artery  â€œMy in-laws obviously came into town and we kept her at school. â€¦She's a very smart and intuitive five-year-old and I didn't want to tell her too much because I don't want to scare her,â€ Laura said. â€œShe wasn't able to see him for 28 days which was probably the hardest part.â€  According to National Institutes of Health, a hemorrhagic stroke is caused by a ruptured blood vessel bleeding into the brain.  Neuroendovascular surgeon Dr. Shamaelah Javed, who was on call that day, said what made Jeremyâ€™s case unique from others sheâ€™s seen was his relatively young age and the major bleeding.  She said Jeremy had a rare malformation affecting only 1 in 600,000 people, and 70 percent of patients in these cases donâ€™t even make it to the hospital.  â€œHonestly, I wasn't expecting that he would have such a remarkable recovery,â€ Javed said. â€œAnd all this is basically attributed to the kind of care that he got in the in the hospital along with the treatment we offered.â€  Javed said the use of new devices and technology helped throughout the process.  â€œThis is like a miracle because his chances of walking out of the hospital were very long,â€ she said. â€œHim surviving was one thing but being disabledâ€”severely disabledâ€”was another fear that I had.  â€œBut he just came back to see me a couple of weeks ago and he's doing very well. He's recovered a lot. So, I think the new treatment modalities that we have has made a huge difference in his recovery.â€  After surgery, Javed said most of his aneurysms had healed and bleeding stopped.  â€œDr. Javed came to the waiting room and when she said that I just fell the ground, thanking God that he's here and he's going to be ok and we're going to get through this,â€ Laura said. â€œWeâ€™ve still got a long road ahead of us (but) he has beat all odds and progressing every single day.â€  During Jeremyâ€™s time in the ICU, Laura said that she visited 40 days straight, not missing a day to check on her husband. Now, he is undergoing rehabilitation and looks forward to recovering from the traumatic experience.  The Simmons family returned to the hospital Monday for an event honoring stroke patients during Survive Stroke Week. Observed from May 15 through 21, the week is an opportunity to spread awareness of signs and symptoms, and the importance of calling 911 immediately if someone has a stroke.  Javed said that people of all ages should watch out for strokes. She suggested people live a healthy lifestyle and get medical checkups regularly.  Laura urges people to seek treatment immediately if theyâ€™re experiencing symptoms.  â€œIf there's something unusual like migraines or numbness to your arms or blurred vision, just don't waste any time. Get to the doctor immediately,â€ she said. â€œAnd obviously, as anybody knows, you're your biggest advocate for yourself and your health. Talk as a family. I had no idea that strokes ran in both sides of this family very strongly and I didn't realize this until he was in the hospital.â€  As Jeremy continues to make progress during his recovery process, he looks forward to playing with his daughter, returning to work and golfing in his free time.

Onni Group is in trouble over its $408 million loan connected to the Wilshire Courtyard office complex on the Miracle Mile, The Real Deal has learned.  The commercial mortgage-backed securities loan from Natixis has been sent to special servicing, ahead of its expected expiration in July, according to data from Trepp and Morningstar Credit Information and Analytics. Onni Group did not respond to a request for comment.  Onni has an option to extend the loan by another year, according to the Morningstar data. However, this option requires the buildingâ€™s income to be 1.1 times the monthly debt service â€” a requirement Onni is not currently achieving, therefore triggering the special servicing.  Onni bought the 1 million-square-foot office complex at 5750 Wilshire Boulevard for $630 million in 2019, taking it from the hands of Tishman Speyer. Months later, it scored WeWork as an anchor tenant, occupying about 32 percent of the space â€” a deal hailed as a win for Onni, given WeWorkâ€™s $47 billion valuation at the time.  The same year, Onni negotiated the CMBS loan and a $69.4 million mezzanine loan from Brookfield, according to a report from DBRS Morningstar.  But the timing was inopportune. WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann was ousted as CEO a few months later after a failed attempt to take the company public. By 2022, WeWork had vacated its entire 335,000-square-foot lease.  Sign Up for the undefined Newsletter SIGN UP By signing up, you agree to TheRealDeal Terms of Use and acknowledge the data practices in our Privacy Policy.  At the end of 2022, the campus was about 46 percent vacant and the firm reported net cash flow of $20 million â€” down from $30.2 million when the CMBS loan was issued, according to Morningstar data.  Tenancy at the property, and therefore income, has been a rollercoaster since then.  In January, Sony Pictures signed a deal to lease 225,000 square feet at the building â€” a major boost for the property.  But three months later, the loanâ€™s special servicer said two major tenants â€” Media Brands Worldwide and Sky Dance Media â€” were expected to vacate the property once their respective leases expire later this year. Together, the two had occupied 165,000 square feet of space. Neither company responded to requests for comment.  However, unlike many office owners with floating rate debt, Onni has been feeling less of the pain that has come with rising interest rates, given it purchased a rate cap when it secured the loan in 2019.  Onni has been paying an interest rate of 3.75 percent on the loan since July of last year, loan data shows, coming out to about $1.3 million a month interest or $15.6 million a year.

Whatâ€™s true of the Indiana Dunes is true of any body of water. Danger lurks under the surface.  There have been more than 20 drownings in these Lake Michigan waters since 2010.  In 2013, one drowning was hundreds of yards away from the lake. In fact, this threat to a 6-year-old boy didnâ€™t involve a drop of water. And its unthinkable occurrence astounded the world.  It was a July day on a family outing to the popular beach at Mt. Baldy. a 126-foot dune an hourâ€™s drive from Chicago. The Woessner family made that trip from their home in Sterling, Illinois.  Thatâ€™s where we found Nathanâ€™s parents, to take us back to that traumatic summer day a decade ago.  â€œIt pretty much started out as a long weekend, camping with friends,â€ Greg recalled. â€œThere was a trail going up to the top of the dunes.â€  Nathan and his friend were following their dads. Suddenly, a panicked call to the dads from the friend who said Nathan disappeared in a hole. Through his initial confusion, there it was: â€œPlain as day, a round, black hole about 15-18 inches in diameter perfectly round hole right straight down,â€ Greg said.  Greg could hear Nathan, but couldnâ€™t see him.  â€œ(I) was actually talking with Nathan, he was still down there, you could tell he was worked up, scared. Just pretty much trying to clam him down. Weâ€™ll get to you, donâ€™t worry,â€ Greg said.  But then, seconds later, as Greg and his friend were digging, the hole collapsed.  Nathanâ€™s friend ran down to get help, other dad ran over the dune to the parking lot to a phone to call 911. By then the other boy made it to Nathanâ€™s mom.  â€œJust by the tone of his voice and his expression, he was just so frightened, and it frightened me,â€ Faith remembered. â€œMy mind couldnâ€™t grasp or understand and I just remember, â€˜no, no, no, no!'â€  Together, on their knees, furiously clawing at the sand, the situation was dire.  â€œI was digging, Greg was digging, we were digging with all of our might, and the sand, it was so unforgiving,â€ Faith said. â€œI remember praying, immediately praying, asking God to give him air to breathe, to hold him and I kept repeating that over and over. â€˜Hold him, give him air to breathe.'â€  Emergency responders arrived. Strangers joined in. With shovels at first â€” then excavating equipment.  â€œIf you ever dig in sand, youâ€™re never getting anywhere, unless you try to get so big,â€ Greg said.  A backhoe was brought in â€” but still no sign of Nathan.  â€œI remember telling (God), â€˜I need him back I need you to give him back to me. I know heâ€™s special but I need him back,â€™ and it was that same prayer over and over and over,â€ Faith said.  Agonizingly. The effort stretched on. Greg: â€œAt this point, itâ€™s been so long they were on a recovery mission now, and not a rescue.â€  Josh Zimmer was prepared for the worst. He was called upon to bring his bigger backhoe to pick up where the smaller one left off. Together they did the careful work of digging.  â€œItâ€™s very slow and meticulous,â€ Zimmer said. â€œRyan had a probe which is just a metal rod itâ€™s about 4 foot down probing the ground to see if he could feel something. And then we would do a grid and I would nice and gentle two inches at a time.â€  Then, the news finally came. More than three hours later. Nearly 12 feet underground. They reached Nathan after unearthing 400 tons of sand. But as many feared, the outcome was grim. His body was limp and cold. He had no pulse.  â€œI donâ€™t know if you want to call it a mood but it was quiet and sad and still because nobody knew, he had no vital signs,â€ Zimmer recalled.  And in that moment of darkness, as Greg and Faith were on their way to the hospital to identify the body, is where the Miracle on Mt. Baldy was revealed; a paramedic noticed a wound on Nathanâ€™s face was bleeding, telling him his heart was still pumping.  â€œThey went into a frenzy suddenly he was back and they were doing everything they could to stabilize him,â€ Faith said.  â€œThey rushed us over to the hospital,â€ Greg struggles to find the words, and motions toward his wife. â€œThatâ€™s the point right there in the waiting room, but he came in, right to her, heâ€™s alive.â€  Faith replies: â€œBest words I ever heard.â€  Today, Nathan is a student at Unity Christian School in Fulton, where heâ€™s a 16-year-old sophomore.  â€œWell, I donâ€™t remember much about it,â€ Nathan offered. â€œI do remember walking up the hill beside my friend. Next thing I remember is waking up with a bunch of nurses and everyone around me.â€  After a week of treatment at Comer Childrenâ€™s Hospital in Chicago, Nathan bears no sign of his childhood trauma, physically, or emotionally. Heâ€™s a stand out athlete on the schoolâ€™s basketball team. He plays soccer and is a member of the brand new school volleyball team.  What he does have is gratitude.  â€œGod was there and God is the reason Iâ€™m still here today,â€ Nathan said. â€œIâ€™ll just be casually thinking about something and itâ€™ll come to mind. And it reminds me and gives me hope that thereâ€™s a plan and that Iâ€™m meant for something.â€  â€œHe doesnâ€™t live in a way thatâ€™s timid or shy,â€ said Jackie Hass, one of Nathanâ€™s teachers at Unity Christian School. â€œHeâ€™s very vivacious. He takes what happened to him to really understand that life is an opportunity and a gift and you have to enjoy it every day, because he does!â€  â€œEvery experience, every new memory watching him grow, every birthday new sports, new friends,â€ Nathanâ€™s mom said. â€œI have really thoroughly enjoyed watching him experience that, itâ€™s not lost on me that we could have just as easily not had that.â€  Someone else was changed by that day: Josh Zimmer, who also knew he was part of something bigger than any of them could understand.  â€ I just couldnâ€™t go to sleep that night, and I knew God was real,â€ Zimmer said. â€œBecause He did something I know was impossible.â€  That night, he called his familyâ€™s pastor and was baptized in the church.  â€œMy in-laws came, they got out of bed, and my wife and the preacherâ€™s wife, yeah it was a life-changing moment.  How did Nathan survive his time buried in the sand?  â€œThere are stories about a dead tree trunk and an air pocket down in the ground, but I think the Lord was with me the whole time. He has a purpose for me and I donâ€™t think my time was then,â€ Nathan said.  How the void developed in the shifting sands is still being studied, but for everyone involved, there is little doubt about what they witnessed.  â€œGod spoke to me,â€ Faith said. â€œHe spoke to my heart, â€˜Iâ€™m giving him back to you heâ€™s a gift to you, I love you,â€™ it was such an overwhelming feeling of gratitude and awe.â€  Greg offered his hard-earned insight: â€œSlow down and capture and love every moment that you can with your kids, your loved ones.â€

Students look at books during a book fair at Schaumburg Elementary, part of the ReNEW charter network, in New Orleans, Wednesday, April 19, 2023. Mississippi, Alabama and Louisiana have seen a promising turnaround in their student reading scores after passing a series of similar literacy reforms. (AP Photo/Gerald Herbert)  Students look at books during a book fair at Schaumburg Elementary, part of the ReNEW charter network, in New Orleans, Wednesday, April 19, 2023. Mississippi, Alabama and Louisiana have seen a promising turnaround in their student reading scores after passing a series of similar literacy reforms. (AP Photo/Gerald Herbert)  NEW ORLEANS (AP) â€” Itâ€™s a clichÃ© that Kymyona Burk heard a little too often: â€œThank God for Mississippi.â€  As the stateâ€™s literacy director, she knew politicians in other states would say it when their reading test scores were down â€” because at least they werenâ€™t ranked as low as Mississippi. Or Louisiana. Or Alabama.  Lately, the way people talk about those states has started to change. Instead of looking down on the Gulf South, theyâ€™re seeing it as a model.  Mississippi went from being ranked the second-worst state in 2013 for fourth-grade reading to 21st in 2022. Louisiana and Alabama, meanwhile, were among only three states to see modest gains in fourth-grade reading during the pandemic, which saw massive learning setbacks in most other states.  The turnaround in these three states has grabbed the attention of educators nationally, showing rapid progress is possible anywhere, even in areas that have struggled for decades with poverty and dismal literacy rates. The states have passed laws adopting similar reforms that emphasize phonics and early screenings for struggling kids.  â€œIn this region, we have decided to go big,â€ said Burk, now a senior policy fellow at ExcelinEd, a national advocacy group.  These Deep South states were not the first to pass major literacy laws; in fact, much of Mississippiâ€™s legislation was based on a 2002 law in Florida that saw the Sunshine State achieve some of the countryâ€™s highest reading scores. The states also still have far to go to make sure every child can read.  But the country has taken notice of what some have called the Mississippi miracle. Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia , Kentucky and Virginia are among the states that have recently adopted some of the same policies. As Mississippi climbed the rankings, the Barksdale Institute, an influential organization in literacy policy in the state, got phone calls from about two dozen states.  The instituteâ€™s CEO, Kelly Butler, said she tells them thereâ€™s no secret to the strategy.  â€œWe know how to teach reading,â€ she said. â€œWe just have to do it everywhere.â€  All three states have trained thousands of teachers in the so-called science of reading, which refers to the most proven, research-backed methods of teaching reading. Theyâ€™ve dispatched literacy coaches to help teachers implement that training, especially in low-performing schools.  They also aim to catch problems early. That means screening for signs of reading deficiencies or dyslexia as early as kindergarten , informing parents if a problem is found and giving those kids extra support.  The states have consequences in place if schools donâ€™t teach kids how to read , but also offer help to keep kids on track.  Mississippi, for one, holds students back in third grade if they cannot pass a reading test but also gives them multiple chances to pass after intensive tutoring and summer literacy camps. Alabama will adopt a similar retention policy next school year. It also sent over 30,000 struggling readers to summer literacy camps last year. Half of those students tested at grade level by the end of the summer.  At schools like Schaumburg Elementary, part of the ReNEW charter network in New Orleans, the new training has helped teachers zero in on what students need to read better. The share of kindergarteners reading at grade level at the charter network grew from 38% in December 2021 to 55% this spring; first-graders grew from 19% to 43%.  The state requires every K-3 teacher, elementary principal and assistant principal to take a 55-hour training course in the science of reading. Itâ€™s well worth the time, according to Assistant Principal Erika Brown, who said that in college she didnâ€™t learn a thing about teaching kids to read.  â€œI was winging it,â€ she said of her early years in teaching.  During a recent session with four second-grade girls, Brown had the girls spell â€œcrib,â€ asking, â€œWhat are the sounds you hear?â€  Like a choir, they chanted back four individual sounds, counting them with their fingers: â€œc-rrr-i-buh.â€ This was one of the techniques Brown had learned in the training; counting four sounds, or phonemes, gave students a clue that the word had four letters. Increased screening also helped the school identify these girls as needing extra help.  â€œAre yâ€™all ready for a challenge word?â€ Brown asked, and the girls shouted, â€œYeah!â€ Their faces fell when Brown revealed the word: bedbug. They had no idea what the word even meant. But with Brownâ€™s gentle guidance, the girls broke down the word into six phonemes. They were even ready for another challenge.  â€œCan we spell cock-a-roach?â€ one of the girls asked.  A second-grader in the school, Joshua Lastie, said he likes how his teacher helps him if he trips over a hard word, like â€œhappenedâ€ or â€œsuddenly.â€  â€œThe school is trying to make the words way easier for kids,â€ said Joshua, 7.  One challenge that comes with the emphasis on small-group intervention is the strain on scheduling and staffing. Literacy coaches from the state are helping the charter network strategize on how to reach all students. One resource the state canâ€™t provide, says Lisa Giarratano, the chief academic officer at ReNEW, is time.  In a national climate where education debates are often polarizing, the three Gulf states passed their sweeping education reforms with bipartisan support, starting with Mississippiâ€™s in 2013. Louisiana state Rep. Richard Nelson, a Republican who has championed literacy reform, said pointing to laws passed in other Deep South states made it easier for him to introduce legislation and â€œsell across party lines.â€  â€œEvery time I present a bill, I say, â€˜Look, Mississippi has very similar challenges to what we have in Louisiana, and theyâ€™ve been able to make this work,â€™â€ Nelson said.  There is still far to go for children in the Gulf South, especially considering the disruptions to schooling from the pandemic and several major hurricanes and tornadoes. Mississippi, after stellar gains in the 2019 National Assessment of Education Progress , saw reading scores drop in 2022, although they are still at the national average. Around two out of five Louisiana third-graders, a particularly hard-hit age group , could not read at grade level at the end of last year. The same goes for over one-fifth of third-graders in Alabama.  Still, evidence suggests these states have made promising gains for low-income kids in particular. In 2019, Alabama ranked 49th in NAEP reading scores for low-income fourth-graders; in 2022, it ranked 27th. Amid the pandemic that saw most states lose ground, Louisiana soared from 42nd to 11th. Mississippi ranks second-highest in the country, after Florida.  Alabamaâ€™s state superintendent of education, Eric Mackey, says he has confidence in the reforms â€” in part because theyâ€™ve worked before. Alabama invested heavily in training on the science of reading, then known as phonics, in the early 2000s, and scores rose. Then the Great Recession hit, teachers and literacy coaches got laid off, and the state lost its gains.  Alabama has learned its lesson, Mackey said.  â€œWe have to break that cycle of generational poverty. One of the best ways to do that is to make multiple generations of readers,â€ Mackey said. â€œThis is something that we have to be in for the long haul.â€  ___  The Associated Press education team receives support from the Carnegie Corporation of New York. The AP is solely responsible for all content.

THOMASTON, Conn. (NewsNation) â€” The Vatican is now investigating an extraordinary event that allegedly took place during a mass at a Roman Catholic Church in Thomaston back in March, leaving the faithful in awe.  Rev. Joseph Crowley, the head of the St. Maximilian Kolbe Parish, was leading Mass at St. Thomas Church in Thomaston when he reported the wafers distributed during Communion multiplied inside the ciborium, which is the container used to hold the wafers, also referred to as Communion host.  â€œGod duplicated himself in this moment. Very powerful, very awesome, very real, very shocking. But also, it happens,â€ Crowley said.  A parishioner who was assisting with distributing the Communion wafers allegedly reported that there was a shortage of hosts. However, they then found there were plenty of wafers remaining.  Now, the alleged event is being investigated as a possible â€œmiracleâ€ by the Vatican.  Although the multiplication of communion wafers may seem relatively inconsequential, it holds great significance for Catholics.  In the 21st century, only four eucharistic miracles have been recognized throughout the world, according to Magis Center.  The Eucharist, or Communion, is considered the holiest sacrament in the Catholic faith. Catholics believe the bread and wine become the literal body and blood of Jesus Christ during the blessing, rather than mere symbols of his presence.  The news quickly reached the Archdiocese of Hartford, prompting an investigation to determine whether a genuine miracle had occurred within the church.  Now, the Vaticanâ€™s Dicastery for the Doctrine of Faith, the entity responsible for safeguarding the Catholic faith worldwide, has been alerted and has initiated its own investigation into the matter.  The alleged miracle at St. Thomas Church has a special connection to the late Father Michael McGivney, the founder of the Knights of Columbus. He spent the final years of his clerical career at St. Thomas Church and is just one more verified miracle away from final consideration for sainthood.  If McGivney were to be canonized, he would become the first man born in the United States ever to be elevated to sainthood.  The Catholic Church has a meticulous process for verifying miracles. The Vaticanâ€™s investigation is expected to take approximately two weeks.  Regardless of the outcome of the investigation, the reported miracle has reignited debates about faith, miracles and the supernatural.  Devan Markham contributed to this report.

David Hunter, 75, is accused of killing his wife of 56 years, Janice, who suffered from terminal blood cancer, in 2021. His lawyers contend it was assisted suicide. He has pleaded not guilty.  Cyprus does not have laws permitting assisted dying, and very few facilities offer palliative care.  Hunter, a retired miner, said his wife's illness saw her quality of life deteriorate markedly in the last three to four years before her death, with her days spent only at a hospital or at home. Irish musician Hozier has said that people's "obsession" with the artificial intelligence program ChatGPT is "more interesting than the program itself."  "I do find our obsession with it [ChatGPT] very interesting," Hozier told the Associated Press when asked about it.  "I think that's more interesting than the actual program itself, to be honest.  "And I'm sure that there's coders that will dispute that. Yeah, this is remarkable.  "But I mean, it's just the logical conclusion of probability. SHELBY, N.C. (WBTV/Gray News) - Three people are dead after a truck fleeing law enforcement crashed into a home in Shelby, North Carolina, on Sunday, WBTV reports.  The incident started in Blacksburg, South Carolina, according to the Cherokee County Sheriffâ€™s Office.  According to deputies, dispatch received a call Sunday around 12:55 a.m. that a white pickup was following and shooting into the callerâ€™s Dodge Charger.  After the chase reached North Carolina, the 911 call was transferred around 1:07 a.m. to the Cleveland County dispatch center.  Deputies from Cleveland County say they tried to stop the suspects, but the truck fled by running a red light and headed onto Highway 74 West, turned onto Dekalb Street and turned off the headlights.  According to deputies, they lost sight of the truck momentarily but found it crashed into the home.  The pickup driver allegedly fled from deputies by running a red light. The truck headed onto Highway 74 West, turned onto Dekalb Street and the headlights were turned off before crashing into a house.  The homeowner said that after nearly 50 years of living in the home on Suttle Street, heâ€™s glad to still have his life. Others in the neighborhood said the incident was unlike anything theyâ€™ve ever seen.  â€œWhat I see is a lot of destruction and a lot of craziness,â€ neighbor Franklin Batten said. â€œI never seen bodies before or people die in an accident like this before. I never witnessed it in my life.â€  Officials with the Shelby Police Department said six men were in the car at the time, five between the ages of 15 and 20.  Officers say three of the men have died, three were taken to the hospital and one was released.  No one in the car that was being chased was hurt.  â€œGiven the relentlessness with which these suspects pursued and shot at the victims, it is a miracle that no one in the victimsâ€™ car was injured. I am proud of the joint effort between all the involved agencies to work through this investigation,â€ Cleveland County Sheriff Alan Norman said.  Copyright 2023 WBTV via Gray Media Group, Inc. A wildlife rescue group in the Houston area is calling the birth of two fawns a miracle after their mother was hit by a car and shot in the head.  "Itâ€™s just the timing of the stars and everything aligning," said Celina Foxworth.  SUGGESTED: Pasadena bee attack leaves family dog clinging to life, they blame CenterPoint Energy  On Friday, All Things Wild Rehabilitation received a call about an injured deer near Atascocita. The deer was found fatally wounded after being hit by a car. A game warden arrived and shot the deer in the head to try and end the animalâ€™s suffering.  "Thatâ€™s part of their job," said Glen Bryant, President of All Things Wild Rehabilitation. "You wouldnâ€™t want someone that is in bad shape to be left on oxygen just to keep them around if theyâ€™re in a lot of pain. Itâ€™s the same way for the animal. Theyâ€™re here to do whatâ€™s best for the animal."  However, when rescuers arrived the injured deer was still alive. It managed to survive getting hit by a car and being shot. Then, the wildlife group noticed movement in the deerâ€™s belly. The nearly dead deer was pregnant.  "Weâ€™re sitting there seeing the babies move and going, theyâ€™re still viable at this point," said Bryant. "If theyâ€™re moving, we should give them a chance." "Honestly, we didnâ€™t think we were going to make it there in time," said Foxworth.  "She wasnâ€™t in great shape by any means, but she definitely held on long enough to save her babies," said Ashley Scott. "She had to of known what she was doing."  Moments before the doeâ€™s death, crews performed an emergency C-section and pulled two fawns from her body.  "It makes you really proud," said Foxworth. "It makes your heart smile and bring a tear to your eyes to know that you did something good in this crazy world."  All Things Wild plans to care for the fawns until they reach a safe age to be released into the wild.  "It was a miracle that they survived," said Scott. "They have a good chance of growing up and being back in the wild. Theyâ€™re in good hands, thatâ€™s for sure."  If youâ€™d like to help these deer, or other animals at All Things Wild, click HERE.

After tying the game in the last minute, the Gators lost in the last ten seconds to the Fighting Irish. The close game came to an end after Notre Dame gained draw control in the seconds to remain, stripping UF of any chance to pull off a miracle.  The No. 6 Florida Gators (17-4, 5-1 AAC) lost to the No. 8 Notre Dame Fighting Irish (15-5, 6-3 ACC) 16-15 Sunday in the National Collegiate Athletics Association Womenâ€™s Lacrosse Championship tournament.  â€œTo play a team like that, who is so good, you need to play a full 60 minute game,â€ Florida head coach Amanda Oâ€™Leary said.  Notre Dame scored the first goal of the game after gaining draw control. However, the Gators quickly showed their opponent this would be a close matchup and scored three consecutive goals in the minutes that followed.  Florida senior Emily Heller scored the first goal for UF in the 11th minute. Following was a goal from Gators junior Ashley Gonzalez fed by her teammate junior Maggi Hall. The third goal was from Florida sophomore Emma LoPinto. UF took an early 3-2 advantage through the first period.  Notre Dame junior Aline Maseker defended well against Florida junior Danielle Pavinelli in the second periodâ€™s seventh minute. However, she was unsuccessful. Pavinelli tied the game, 5-5.  The Fighting Irish stepped up and put three more goals on the scoreboard. The half concluded with Notre Dame in front, 8-5.  UF gained draw control to start the second half. Hall was the first to put a ball in the back of the net off of a free position shot. It marked her 45th goal of the season. The teams were back-and-forth for the rest of the third period keeping the score close.  Notre Dame senior Kasey Choma followed Hall's goal with one of her own. Shortly after was another goal from Heller, and two more from the Irish.  Hall and LoPinto scored the last three from UF, but Notre Dame still led at the end of the period, 12-10.  With 15 minutes left, it became a one goal game.  Choma was the first to score. UF responded less than a minute later. Florida junior Madison Waters scored off an assist from LoPinto with 13 minutes remaining.  Enjoy what you're reading? Get content from The Alligator delivered to your inbox Subscribe Now  Hall and LoPinto scored again and Pavinelli tied the game at 15-15 with a minute left.  Choma broke the tie and scored with ten seconds on the clock to put Notre Dame in front, 16-15. The Irish won the draw control seconds later and the game was over.  Notre Dameâ€™s womenâ€™s lacrosse team will advance to the NCAA Quarterfinals and for the first time since 2019, Florida wonâ€™t.  Contact Madilyn Destefano at mdestefano@alligtor.org. Follow her on Twitter @DestefanoMadi.

IMAGE: Nitish Rana and Rinku Singh continued their brilliant run of form in IPL 2023. Photograph: BCCI  IPL 2023 has been a roller coaster ride with nail-biting finishes and heart-stopping moments, but Sunday's doubleheaders were a snooze-fest.  CSK fans must have clung to their seats hoping for a miracle from their beloved Thala to pull off a master-stroke, but alas, it was not meant to be.  Nitish Rana and Rinku Singh continued their brilliant run of form as they pulled off one of the surprise results of the season to breach fortress Chepauk, with the Kolkata Knight Riders defeating Chennai Super Kings by six wickets.  Chasing 145, KKR lost three quick wickets in the Powerplay with Deepak Chahar taking three wickets, dismissing Rahmunllah Gurbaz, Jason Roy and Venkatesh Iyer, before the CSK spin attack even came into the game.  Kolkata looked in trouble at 33-3, but the left-handed pair Rinku and Rana put on a hall of fame display on how to play spin at Chepauk with a 99-run partnership to take their side home with nine balls to spare.  IMAGE: Rinku Singh celebrates his half century. Photograph: BCCI  Rana remained unbeaten with 57 off 44 balls while Rinku scored a 43-ball 54. This was the highest fourth wicket partnership in the IPL at the M A Chidambaram stadium.  The match will be remembered for RR's outstanding performance, which showcased how to play spin in challenging conditions and keep the pressure on a formidable opponent.  IMAGE: Nitish Rana slammed the winning runs. Photograph: BCCI  Initially, Rinku was the aggressor, but Rana picked up pace and extinguished any hope of CSK defending the total. Rana made the most of a dropped catch on 18 by Matheesha Pathirana in the deep to reach his fifty and stood firm to hit the winning runs.  Rinku, who became an IPL sensation with his five sixes off the last five balls against the Gujarat Titans to conjure up a miracle win for Kolkata last month, struck another fifty of the season before being run out. He was eventually awarded the player of the match.
